{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|(341843) 2008 EV|5}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | name = (341843) {{mp|2008 EV|5}} | background = #FFC2E0 | image = 2008 EV5 orbit 2010.png | image_size = 255 | caption = Diagram of {{mp|2008 EV|5}}'s [[List of Earth-crossing minor planets|Earth-crossing]] orbit | discovery_ref =   | discoverer = [[Mount Lemmon Survey|Mount Lemmon Srvy.]] | discovery_site = [[Mount Lemmon Observatory|Mount Lemon Obs.]] | discovered = 4 March 2008 | mpc_name = (341843) {{mp|2008 EV|5}} | alt_names = {{mp|2008 EV|5}} | pronounced = | named_after = | mp_category = [[Near-Earth object|NEO]]{{·}}[[Aten asteroid|Aten]]{{·}}[[Potentially hazardous object|PHA]]  | orbit_ref =   | epoch = 4 September 2017 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2458000.5) | uncertainty = 1 | observation_arc = 2.10 yr (768 days) | aphelion = 1.0383 [[Astronomical unit|AU]] | perihelion = 0.8783 AU | semimajor = 0.9583 AU | eccentricity = 0.0835 | period = 0.94 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (343 days) | mean_anomaly = 213.55[[Degree (angle)|°]] | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|1.0506|sup=ms}} / day | inclination = 7.4368° | asc_node = 93.390° | arg_peri = 234.81° | moid = {{convert|0.0149|AU|LD|abbr=on|lk=on}} | dimensions = ({{val|420|×|410|×|390}}) [[Metre|m]] | mean_diameter = {{val|0.370|0.006}} km
{{val|0.400|0.014}} km
{{val|0.400|0.034}} km
{{val|0.400|0.050}} km | rotation = {{val|3.717|0.008|ul=h}}
3.725 h
{{val|3.7255|0.002}} h
{{val|7.2|}} h
{{val|10.200|0.002}} h | albedo = {{val|0.104|0.312}}
{{val|0.12|0.04}}
{{val|0.13|0.05}}
{{val|0.137|0.013}}
{{val|0.1373|0.0129}} | spectral_type = [[X-type asteroid|X]] {{·}}[[C-type asteroid|C]] {{·}}[[S-type asteroid|S]] {{small|(assumed)}} | abs_magnitude = 19.7{{·}}19.91{{·}}20.0{{·}}{{val|20.0|0.4}} }} '''{{mp|(341843) 2008 EV|5}}''', provisional designation {{mp|2008 EV|5}}, is a sub-kilometer [[asteroid]], classified as [[near-Earth object]] and [[potentially hazardous asteroid]] of the [[Aten asteroid|Aten group]], approximately {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=off}} in diameter. It was discovered on 4 March 2008, by astronomers of the [[Mount Lemmon Survey]] at [[Mount Lemmon Observatory]] near Tucson, Arizona, United States. == Physical characteristics == [[File:Asteroid-2008EV5-ShapeModel-20111006.gif|thumb|200px|left|Radar-based shape model of {{mp|2008 EV|5}}]] {{mp|2008 EV|5}} is an [[oblate spheroid]] {{convert|400|m|ft|abbr=on}} in diameter. It rotates very slowly in a [[Retrograde and prograde motion|retrograde]] direction. There is a {{convert|150|m|ft|abbr=on}} diameter [[Concave function|concave]] feature, possibly an [[impact crater]], or a relic feature from a previous episode of rapid rotation that caused the asteroid's shape to reconfigure. Visible and near-infrared spectroscopy show that {{mp|2008 EV|5}}'s composition is similar to that of [[carbonaceous chondrite]] meteorites. == Sample return mission == {{mp|2008 EV|5}} is the preliminary baseline target of a proposed [[Sample return mission|sample-return]] [[NASA]] mission called [[Asteroid Redirect Mission|ARM]]. Besides the asteroid {{mp|2008 EV|5}}, several other asteroids, including [[25143 Itokawa|Itokawa]] and [[101955 Bennu|Bennu]], are being considered for this mission. == Origin and orbital history == {{mp|2008 EV|5}} started its existence as part of a much larger body in the asteroid belt, with a likely diameter greater than 100 kilometers. {{mp|2008 EV|5}}'s immediate history likely started when its parent body experienced a large cratering event or, more likely, a catastrophic disruption event that resulted in a highly fractured, shattered, or reaccumulated object (rubble pile). As a result, {{mp|2008 EV|5}} may have been produced as a reassembly of ejected fragments. The location of what is now {{mp|2008 EV|5}} within this parent body is unknown. Given the available modeling work and data, the most plausible source family candidates for {{mp|2008 EV|5}} are [[495 Eulalia|Eulalia]], [[Nysa family|New Polana]], and [[163 Erigone|Erigone]]. This assumes that {{mp|2008 EV|5}}'s true albedo is considerably lower than 10%. If it does have a high albedo, a plausible source would be a population of high-albedo [[C-type asteroids]] in the inner asteroid belt. Second tier candidate families for the high-albedo case are [[Baptistina family|Baptistina]] and [[Pallas family|Pallas]]. From here, the newly liberated {{mp|2008 EV|5}} began to change via the forces referred to as the [[Yarkovsky effect|Yarkovsky]] and [[Yarkovsky–O'Keefe–Radzievskii–Paddack effect|YORP]] effects. The Yarkovsky effect describes a small force that affects orbital motion. It is caused by sunlight; when objects heat up in the Sun, they reradiate the energy away as heat, which in turn creates a tiny thrust. This recoil acceleration is much weaker than solar and planetary gravitational forces, but it can produce substantial orbital changes over timescales ranging from many millions to billions of years. The same physical phenomenon also creates a thermal torque that probably caused {{mp|2008 EV|5}} to take on a top-like appearance. Dynamical models indicate that {{mp|2008 EV|5}} migrated inward across the inner asteroid belt over long timescales (i.e. the order of ~0.01–1 Gyr) until it reached a planetary gravitational resonance that drove it into the near-Earth asteroid (NEA) population over a timescale of the order of ~1 Myr. From there, gravitational interactions with both the planets and resonances allowed it to reach its current orbit within a few Myr to a few tens of Myr. == 2008 close approach == On 23 December 2008, {{mp|2008 EV|5}} made a close approach to Earth at a distance of 8.4 lunar distances (0.022 AU, 3.2 million km), its closest until 2169. Its brightness peaked on December 26 about 13.2 [[apparent magnitude|magnitude]]. [[File:2008 EV5 skyview 2008.png|thumb|left|500px|Path of {{mp|2008 EV|5}} close approach, with 3 day motion markers]] {{clear|left}} == See also == * [[Asteroid Redirect Mission]] * [[List of minor planets: 341001–342000]] == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |type = 2010-04-11 last obs. |title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser: 341843 (2008 EV5) |url = https://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2341843 |publisher = [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate = 17 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = 341843 (2008 EV5) |work = [[Minor Planet Center]] |url = https://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=341843 |accessdate = 17 January 2018}} {{cite web |title = Asteroids and comets rotation curves – (341843) |last = Behrend |first = Raoul |publisher = Geneva Observatory |url = http://obswww.unige.ch/~behrend/page5cou.html#341843 |accessdate = 17 January 2018}} {{cite journal |display-authors = 6 |first1 = A. |last1 = Mainzer |first2 = T. |last2 = Grav |first3 = J. |last3 = Bauer |first4 = J. |last4 = Masiero |first5 = R. revision.text:
{{Infobox aircraft occurrence |name = Tupolev Tu-144 |occurrence_type = Accident |image = Tupolev Tu-144 CCCP-77102 LEB 02.06.73 edited-3.jpg |image_size = 250 |alt = |caption = The Tu-144S CCCP-77102 displaying at the 1973 Paris Air Show on the day before it crashed. |date = 3 June 1973, 15:29 |type = Structural failure in flight due to sharp manoeuvres |site = [[Goussainville, Val-d'Oise]] |coordinates = |aircraft_type = [[Tupolev Tu-144|Tupolev Tu-144S]] |aircraft_name = |operator = [[Aeroflot]] |tail_number = CCCP-77102 |origin = [[Paris–Le Bourget Airport]] |destination = Paris–Le Bourget Airport |crew = 6 |fatalities = 14 (6 in the aircraft and 8 on the ground) |survivors = 0 }}
The '''1973 Paris Air Show crash''' was the crash of the second production [[Tupolev Tu-144]] at [[Goussainville, Val-d'Oise]], France, which killed all six crew and eight people on the {{nowrap|ground.<ref name=srrsscr>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8B5OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Pe0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6732%2C1543669 |work=Spokesman-Review |location=(Spokane, Washington, U.S.) |agency=Associated Press |title=Russian SST crashes |date=June 4, 1973 |page=1}}</ref><ref name=mlssv>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=A_EjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6853%2C605260 |work=Milwaukee Sentinel |location=(Wisconsin, U.S.)|agency=UPI |title=Soviet SST crash kills 14 |date=June 4, 1973 |page=1}}</ref>}} The crash, at the [[Paris Air Show]] on Sunday, 3 June {{nowrap|1973,<ref name=fftnkld>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uJVAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IaUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2298%2C524076|work=Glasgow Herald |title=15 killed as Russia's Concorde explodes |date=June 4, 1973 |page=1}}</ref>}} damaged the development program of the Tupolev Tu-144.<ref>[http://www.ina.fr/economie-et-societe/justice-et-faits-divers/video/CAF94004211/accident-tupolev-144-au-salon-du-bourget.fr.html " Crash of the Tupolev 144 on 3 June 1973 video."] [[Office de Radiodiffusion Télévision Française|ORTF]], 8:00 p.m. news broadcasting, 3 June 1973, on the [[Institut national de l'audiovisuel|INA]] website , ina.fr.</ref>
One theory is that a French [[Dassault Mirage III|Mirage]] jet sent to photograph the aircraft without the knowledge of the Soviet crew caused the pilots to take evasive manoeuvres, resulting in the {{nowrap|crash.<ref name="timeeurope">{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/europe/magazine/2000/0807/concordski.html|title=The Concordski TU-144: A blast from the past|last=Zarakohvich|first=Yuri|date=7 August 2000|work=Time Europe|access-date=27 December 2010}}</ref>}} Another theory is that in a rivalry with the Anglo-French [[Concorde]], the pilots attempted a manoeuvre that was beyond the capabilities of {{nowrap|the aircraft.<ref name="timeeurope" /><ref name="concordski" />}}
==Accident== [[file:RIAN archive 368835 A Tupolev Tu-144 supersonic transport in mid-air.jpg|thumb|left|Tupolev Tu-144S CCCP-77102 with landing gear and canard foreplanes extended. (19 May 1973)]] The aircraft involved was Tupolev Tu-144S CCCP-77102, manufacturer's [[Serial code|serial number]] 01-2, the second production Tu-144.<ref name="aviation">{{cite book|last=Greenwood|first=John T.|editor=Robin D. S. Higham |editor2=John T. Greenwood |editor3=Von Hardesty|title=Russian aviation and air power in the twentieth century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cpynoFM-Jf4C&pg=PA174|year=1998|publisher=Routledge|page=174|chapter=The Designers and their Aircraft|isbn=978-0-7146-4784-5}}</ref> The aircraft had first flown on 29 March 1972.<ref name="ASN030672">{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19730603-0 |title=CCCP-77102 Accident description |publisher=Aviation Safety Network |access-date=26 December 2010}}</ref> This aircraft had been heavily modified compared to the initial prototype, now featuring engine [[nacelle]]s split on either side of the fuselage, landing gear that retracted into the nacelles, and retractable [[Canard (aeronautics)#Close-coupled canard|canards]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Owen|first=Kenneth|title=Concorde: story of a supersonic pioneer |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VzNUJlX7CXoC&pg=PA154|year=2001|publisher=Science Museum|isbn=978-1-900747-42-4|page=154|chapter=The rivals}}</ref> The pilot was Mikhail Kozlov,<ref name="concordski">{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gnI8IGtKy64C&pg=PA595|title=Concordski and Concorde|last=Gunston|first=Bill|authorlink=Bill Gunston|date=7 June 1973|work=New Scientist|access-date=27 December 2010}}</ref> and the co-pilot was Valery M. Molchanov.<ref name="Flight140673b" /> Also on board were G. N. Bazhenov, the flight navigator, V. N. Benderov, deputy chief designer and engineer major-general, B. A. Pervukhin, senior engineer, and A. I. Dralin, flight engineer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.kommersant.com/p-8675/r_533/Events/|title=Once Upon a Time|date=3 June 2006|work=Kommersant|access-date=27 December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012145346/http://www.kommersant.com/p-8675/r_533/Events/|archive-date=12 October 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The crash occurred in front of 250,000 people, including designer [[Alexei Tupolev]], towards the end of the show.<ref name="concordski" />
During the show, there was a "fierce competition between the Anglo-French Concorde and the Russian Tu-144".<ref name="concordski" /> The Soviet pilot, Mikhail Kozlov, had bragged that he would outperform the Concorde.<ref name="concordski" /> "Just wait until you see us fly," he was quoted as saying. "Then you'll see something."<ref name = "deadly">{{cite news | url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,910688,00.html | title=DISASTERS: Deadly Exhibition | work=Time | date=18 June 1973}}</ref> On the final day of the show, the [[Concorde]], which was not yet in production, performed its demonstration flight first.<ref name=concordski/> Its performance was later described as being unexciting, and it has been theorized that Kozlov was determined to show how much better his aircraft was.<ref name = "deadly" />
Once in flight, the aircraft made what appeared to be a landing approach, with the landing gear out and the "moustache" canards extended, but then with all four engines full power, climbed rapidly. Possibly stalling below {{convert|2000|ft|m|abbr=on}}, the aircraft pitched over and went into a steep dive.<ref name="concordski" /> Trying to pull out of the subsequent dive with the engines again at full power, the Tu-144 broke up in mid-air, possibly due to overstressing the airframe. The left wing came away first, and then the aircraft disintegrated and crashed,<ref name="concordski" /><ref name="ASN030672" /><ref name="Flight140673b" /> destroying 15 houses,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/articles/2009/06/05/327190/paris-air-show-100-years-of-paris-air-show-highlights.html|title=Paris Air Show: 100 years of Paris air show highlights|date=5 June 2009|website=Flightglobal|access-date=27 December 2010}}</ref> and killing all six people on board the Tu-144 and eight more on the ground.<ref name="ASN030672" /> Three children were among those killed, and sixty people received severe injuries.<ref name="nova" />
==Reactions== The crew of the Tu-144 were buried at the [[Novodevichy Cemetery]] in Moscow on 12 June 1973.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1973/1973%20-%201708.html|title=Tu-144 investigation continues|date=21 June 1973|journal=Flight International |volume=103 |number=3354 |page=938 |access-date=27 December 2010}}</ref>
Following the crash, [[Marcel Dassault]] called for the 1975 Paris Air Show to be held at [[Istres-Le Tubé Air Base|Istres]], which is situated in open country {{convert|40|km|abbr=on}} north west of [[Marseille]].<ref name="Flight140673a">{{cite journal |title=Display dangers |journal=Flight International |number=3353 |volume=103|date=14 June 1973 |page=910 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1973/1973%20-%201650.html}}</ref>
The crash reduced the enthusiasm of [[Aeroflot]] for the Tu-144. Restrictions on the Tu-144 following the Paris Air Show crash meant that it only saw limited service during 1977 and 1978, and it was finally withdrawn following another crash in May 1978.<ref name="aviation" /> The Tu-144's rival, the Concorde, went on to serve with British Airways and Air France for 30 years afterwards, being finally withdrawn from service in 2003 due to rising service costs and the slump in the aviation industry following [[9/11]]. In 2000, Concorde [[Air France Flight 4590]] crashed in [[Paris]], [[France]] killing all 100 passengers & 9 crew as well as 4 people on the ground.
==Causes== ===Investigation=== The accident was investigated by the DTCE<!--what does this stand for?-->, part of the [[French Armed Forces|French Military]], which was responsible for accidents involving prototype aircraft in France. The wreckage was recovered to a hangar at Le Bourget, with some of it being flown by [[Antonov An-22]] to the [[Soviet Union]].<ref name="Flight140673b" >{{cite journal |title=Tu-144 crash investigation |journal=Flight International |date=14 June 1973 |page=908 |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1973/1973%20-%201648.html}}</ref>
===Theories=== [[File:Le Bourget 1973 en.jpg|thumb|Flight profile of Tu-144 and Mirage IIIR{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}]] [[File:Dassault_Mirage_IIIR.jpg|thumb|A French [[Dassault Mirage III]]R fighter jet. Shortly before the accident, a Mirage IIIR had taken off from the airport. A theory for the incident suggests that the Tu-144 swerved to avoid the Mirage and lost control, breaking up before impacting the ground.]] One theory is that the Tu-144 manoeuvred to avoid a French [[Dassault Mirage III|Mirage]] chase plane that was attempting to photograph its unique [[canard (aeronautics)|canards]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.salon.com/technology/ask_the_pilot/2005/06/24/askthepilot142/|title=Ask the pilot|last=Smith|first=Patrick|date=24 June 2005|work=Salon|access-date=27 December 2010}}</ref> which were advanced for the time, and that the French and Soviet governments colluded with each other to cover up such details.<ref name="nova" /> The flight of the Mirage was denied in the original French report of the incident, perhaps because it was engaged in [[industrial espionage]]. More recent reports have admitted the existence of the Mirage (and the fact that the Soviet crew were not told about the Mirage's flight) though not its role in the crash. However, the official press release did state: "though the inquiry established that there was no real risk of collision between the two aircraft, the Soviet pilot was likely to have been surprised."<ref name="nova">[https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/transcripts/2503supersonic.html "Supersonic Spies."] ''Nova'' PBS air date: 27 January 1998.</ref> Howard Moon also stresses that last-minute changes to the flight schedule would have disoriented the pilots in a cockpit with notably poor vision. He also cites an eyewitness who claims the co-pilot had agreed to take a camera with him, which he may have been operating at the time of the evasive manoeuvre.<ref name="nova" /> The initial approach may have been an attempted landing on the wrong runway, which occurred due to a last-minute shortening of the Tu-144's display.<ref name="timeeurope" />
[[Bob Hoover]] believed that the rivalry of the Tu-144 and Concorde led the pilot of the Tu-144 to attempt a manoeuvre that went beyond the abilities of the aircraft: "That day, the Concorde went first, and after the pilot performed a high-speed flyby, he pulled up steeply and climbed to approximately 10,000 [feet] before leveling off. When the Tu-144 pilot performed the same manoeuvre he pulled the nose up so steeply l didn't believe he could possibly recover."<ref name="timeeurope" />
Another theory claims that there was deliberate misinformation on the part of the Anglo-French design-team. The main thrust of this theory was that the Anglo-French team knew that the Soviet team was planning to steal the design plans of the Concorde, and the Soviets were allegedly passed false blueprints with a flawed design. The case, it is claimed, contributed to the imprisonment by the Soviets of [[Greville Wynne]] in 1963 for spying.<ref>Wynne, Greville. ''The Man from Odessa''. Dublin: Warnock Books, 1983. {{ISBN|0-586-05709-9}}.</ref><ref name="Wright">Wright, Peter and Paul Greengrass.''Spycatcher: The Candid Autobiography of a Senior Intelligence Officer.'' London: Viking, 1987. {{ISBN|0-670-82055-5}}.</ref>{{failed verification|reason=There is no mention of Concorde in the book|date=February 2018}} Wynne was imprisoned on 11 May 1963 and the development of the Tu-144 was not sanctioned until 16 July.
==See also== *[[Air France Flight 4590]], the 2000 [[Concorde]] crash in France *[[2015 Shoreham Airshow crash]], an accident involving a [[Hawker Hunter]] that failed to complete an aerobatic manoeuvre before crashing into traffic outside [[Shoreham Airport]] {{clear right}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19730603-0 Accident description] on the [[Aviation Safety Network]]

revision.text:
{{pp-move-indef}} {{Multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 250 | header = Blackout: before and after | image1 = Santiago sur segundos antes del apagon.jpg | caption1 = Southern Santiago prior to blackout. | image2 = Santiago sur a oscuras.jpg | caption2 = Southern Santiago during the blackout. }} The '''2010 Chile blackout''' was an electric [[power outage]] that affected most of [[Chile]] on March 14, 2010. It began at 8:44 pm (23:44 GMT) on Sunday and continued into the next day. The power was restored in a few hours in some areas, and by midnight in most areas, except in the [[Biobío Region]].<ref name="sic">[https://www.cdec-sic.cl/noticia_en.php?noticia_id=852 [[Sistema Interconectado Central|CDEC-SIC]] Communicado]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. Retrieved 17 March 2010. {{es icon}}</ref>
The blackout was caused by a failure of a 500 kV [[transformer]] at a [[Electrical substation|substation]] in southern Chile that is part of the [[Sistema Interconectado Central|Central Interconnected System]] (SIC). The affected transformer is located around {{convert|700|km}} south of the capital, [[Santiago, Chile|Santiago]].<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8567910.stm|title= Chile plunged into darkness by power cut|date=15 March 2010|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref> The SIC serves about 93% of the country's population, from [[Taltal]] in the north to the [[Chiloé Island]] in the south, including Santiago.<ref name="sic"/> At one point Santiago was receiving only 8% of the electricity normally required.<ref name="BBC"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jgD1HWniMw6lzC8tOJyT_YnZc-vgD9EEQQN80|title=Blackout leaves millions of Chileans in darkness|last=Vergara|first=Eva|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref>
The blackout interrupted a music concert being held to raise funds for the survivors of the [[2010 Chile earthquake|earthquake that had devastated the country two weeks earlier]].<ref name="BBC"/> In addition, thousands of people had to be rescued from the [[Santiago Metro]] after 20 trains were immobilised and the telephone network was also affected.<ref name="BBC"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jMgcf52UGrMhDzPJXbXJqp1QLvrw|title=Chile hit by massive blackout: emergency office|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Agence France Presse|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref> The fire brigade had to free several people trapped in [[elevator]]s.<ref name="Earth">{{cite news|url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/314197,chile-expects-six-months-of-power-fragility-after-massive-quake.html|title= Chile expects six months of power 'fragility' after massive quake|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Earth News|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref>
The blackout affected 90% of the population and electric service began to be restored after an hour.<ref name="BBC"/> Around 98% of people affected had service restored by March 15, 2010.<ref name="xinhua">{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-03/16/c_13211990.htm|title= Chile's power supply normalized gradually after blackout|date=16 March 2010|publisher=Xinhua|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref> The blackout caused the share price of the [[Enersis]] mining group to fall by 1% to a three-month low, although loss of production was minimal there and at other mining companies in the country because of backup generators.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-15/enersis-falls-leading-chile-index-drop-on-blackout-concern.html|title=Enersis Falls to Three-Month Low on Blackout Concern (Update1)|last=Attwood|first=James|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2010-03-15/chile-will-face-outages-for-a-week-on-quake-damage-pinera-says.html|title=Chile Will Face Outages for a Week on Quake Damage, Pinera Says|last1=Craze|first1=Matt|last2=Orihuela|first2=Rodrigo|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Business Week|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref>
[[President of Chile|President]] [[Sebastián Piñera]] blamed the power failure on the recent earthquake and said the SIC would remain unstable for a week.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Chile's Pinera: Power Grid To Be Unstable For A Week After Blackout |url=http://www.nasdaq.com/aspx/stock-market-news-story.aspx?storyid=201003151120dowjonesdjonline000218&title=chiles-pinera-power-grid-to-be-unstable-for-a-week-after-blackout |agency=Dow Jones Newswires |date=15 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5oJ2FdOmZ?url=http://www.nasdaq.com/aspx/stock-market-news-story.aspx?storyid=201003151120dowjonesdjonline000218&title=chiles-pinera-power-grid-to-be-unstable-for-a-week-after-blackout |archivedate=2010-03-17 |accessdate=17 March 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Other officials stated that the outage was not directly related to the earthquake.<ref name="BBC"/> The energy minister, [[Ricardo Raineri]], said that the electric transmission grid remains in a fragile state and asked Chileans to restrict their use of electricity.<ref name="BBC"/> Raineri stated that during the earthquake the "electricity network suffered various damages, be it in transformers, switches and others".<ref name="Earth"/>
An investigation was started to determine if the failure was due to a lack of maintenance of the transformer.<ref name="xinhua"/> Piñera vowed to get the transformer repaired within 48 hours of the blackout and to get affected transmission lines checked and repaired within seven days.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSN1519628320100315?type=marketsNews|title=UPDATE 1-Chile's power grid unstable for a week – president|date=15 March 2010|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=16 March 2010}}</ref>
==Blackout investigation==
On August 2, 2010, the Chile regulatory authority Superintendency of Electricity and Fuels (SEC) determined that while the blackout was initiated by the equipment failure, the root cause was a widespread lack of coordination between the various companies in the day-to-day operations of the electricity sector. As a result, the SEC laid charges against all 115 companies involved in the electrical sector.
The charges were as follows:
*Each company did not coordinate its day-to-day operations to account for possible events, such as unforeseen transmission line failures. *Each company did not coordinate any necessary actions with others in the electrical system to ensure the safety of the overall electrical system. *Each company did not ensure the safe and efficient operation of the electrical system according to the established general criteria. *Each company did not have established procedures in place for coordinated operation with other companies when needed to ensure system security or when required to maintain quality of service.
Additional charges were filed against [[Endesa (Chile)]], Transquillota, CHILECTRA, and TRANSELEC for either equipment failures in owned facilities or for failure to provide adequate information to Chile's central electrical grid system operator, Center for Economic Load Dispatch (CDEC-SIC). Further charges were also laid for issues at the Alto Jahuel high voltage electrical substation, located south of Santiago, which led to undue delays in recovery of the Metropolitan Region.
The Superintendent of the SEC, Patricia Chotzen, said that "after the technical analysis of the background, as part of a complex investigation, we decided to press charges against the companies involved whom have not made the necessary arrangements, referred to in our regulations."
Asked about whether the blackout may have been caused by the earthquake which had occurred two weeks previous, Chotzen said that "after an event of the magnitude of the earthquake of February, the companies had a duty to increase their level of coordination to avoid a collapse like this one. It is the duty of the utilities that provide a service as fundamental as electricity to ensure continuous and safe supply." The current legislation provided for fines of up to 10 000 AWU.<ref name="SEC formula cargos en contra de 115 empresas eléctricas, 2010-08-02">{{cite news |title=SEC formula cargos en contra de 115 empresas eléctricas|url=http://www.sec.cl/pls/portal/SITIO_WEB.BLACKOUT.show|date=2 August 2010 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Electricity sector in Chile]] {{clear}}
==References== {{Wikinews|Power outage affects many areas of Chile}} {{Portal|Chile|Energy}} {{reflist|2}}
{{Energy in Chile}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:March 2010 Chile Blackout}} [[Category:2010 Chile earthquake|Blackout]] [[Category:Electric power in Chile]] [[Category:Electric power blackouts|Chile, 2010]] [[Category:2010 in Chile|blackout]] [[Category:March 2010 events]]

revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=February 2016}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Year nav|-496}} {{BC year in topic|496}} __NOTOC__ Year '''496 BC''' was a year of the [[Roman calendar|pre-Julian Roman calendar]]. At the time, it was known as the '''Year of the Consulship of Albus and Tricostus''' (or, less frequently, '''year 258 ''[[Ab urbe condita]]'''''). The denomination 496 BC for this year has been used since the early medieval period, when the [[Anno Domini]] [[calendar era]] became the prevalent method in Europe for naming years.
== Events == <onlyinclude>
=== By place ===
==== Greece ==== * [[Hipparchos (son of Charmos)|Hipparchos]], son of [[Charmos]] (a relative of the 6th century BC tyrant [[Peisistratos (Athens)|Peisistratos]]), wins the [[archon]]ship of [[Athens]] as leader of the peace party which argues that resistance against the Persians is useless.
==== Roman Republic ==== * The former [[Etruscan civilization|Etruscan]] [[King of Rome]], [[Tarquinius Superbus]], who has been exiled by the Romans in 509 BC, and his ally [[Octavius Mamilius]], of [[Tusculum]], together with the [[Latin League|Latins]] are defeated by the [[Roman Republic]] army in the [[Battle of Lake Regillus]], near [[Frascati]]. The outcome of this battle establishes Roman supremacy over the Latins.
==== China ==== * [[King Goujian of Yue]] defeats and banishes [[King Fuchai of Wu]], gaining a temporary hegemony in ancient [[China]] during the [[Spring and Autumn period]]. </onlyinclude>
== Births == * [[Sophocles]], [[Athens, Greece|Athenian]] [[dramatist]] and [[wikt:statesman|statesman]] (d. [[406 BC]])
== Deaths == * [[Sun Tzu]], military philosopher and author of [[The Art of War]] (most likely a colloquial date) (b. [[544 BC]]) * [[King Helü of Wu]], king of the [[China|Chinese]] [[Wu (state)|State of Wu]] * [[Marcus Valerius Volusus]] and [[Titus Herminius Aquilinus]], both former [[Roman consul]]s died at the [[Battle of Lake Regillus]] * [[Octavius Mamilius]], ruler of [[Tusculum]] also died at the Battle of Lake Regillus
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:496 Bc}} [[Category:496 BC| ]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = April 9th | film name = '''''9. April''''' | image = 9. April (film).jpg | alt = | caption = Film poster | director = Roni Ezra | producer = {{Plain list | *René Ezra *Tomas Radoor }} | writer = [[Tobias Lindholm]] | starring = {{Plain list | *[[Lars Mikkelsen]] *[[Pilou Asbæk]] <!--- per poster ---> }} | music = Jonas Struck | cinematography = Philippe Kress | editing = Peter Brandt | studio = {{Plain list | *Nordisk Film *TV2 Danmark *Det Danske Filminstitut }} | distributor = Nordisk Film | released = {{Film date|df=y|2015|03|12}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = Denmark | language = Danish | budget = 22 million kr. | gross = }} '''''April 9th''''' ({{lang-da|'''9. april'''}}) is a 2015 [[Denmark|Danish]] war film directed by Roni Ezra and starring [[Pilou Asbæk]] and [[Lars Mikkelsen]]. The film depicts the [[German invasion of Denmark (1940)|German invasion of Denmark]] which commenced on 9 April 1940 and follows a group of Danish [[bicycle infantry]] sent as a vanguard to slow down the German advance until reinforcements can arrive.
The film's budget was 22 million [[Danish krone]] (just over $3 million) and was supported by the [[Danish Film Institute]], [[TV 2 (Denmark)|TV 2]] and the [[Haderslev Municipality]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=LINDEGAARD|first1=SIGNE HAAHR|title=For Gud, konge og fædreland|url=https://jyllands-posten.dk/premium/kultur/article6828213.ece|website=Jyllands Posten|language=Danish}}</ref> The film was released in Danish cinemas on 12 March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|last1=PEDERSEN|first1=KIM|title=Biografklub Danmark-programmet 2014-15|url=http://danske-biografer.dk/biografklub-danmark-programmet-2014-15/|website=Danske-biografer.dk|accessdate=27 February 2015|language=Danish}}</ref>
==Plot== During the night of 9 April 1940, the Danish army is alerted that the German army has crossed the border and Denmark is now at war with Europe's strongest army. In [[German invasion of Denmark (1940)#Fighting in Jutland|South Jutland]], a Danish bicycle infantry company and a motorcycle platoon is ordered to hold off the German advance until reinforcements can arrive but are quickly overwhelmed by superior German forces. During the morning [[Second Lieutenant]] Sand ([[Pilou Asbæk]]) and his platoon of soldiers battle the Germans and then retreat to [[Haderslev]].<ref>{{cite web|title=9. April|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3542188/?ref_=nv_sr_1|website=IMDB.com|accessdate=27 February 2015}}</ref>
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Lars Mikkelsen]] – [[Lieutenant colonel|Lieutenant-Colonel]] Hintz * [[Pilou Asbæk]] – [[Second Lieutenant]] Sand * Gustav Dyekjær Giese – [[Private (rank)|Private]] Andersen * Sebastian Bull Sarning – Private Lundgren * Joachim Fjelstrup – [[Sergeant]] Bundgaard * [[:da:Martin Greis|Martin Greis]] – [[Lieutenant]] Gjermansen * Michael Brostrup – [[Colonel]] Hartz * Elliott Crosset Hove – Private Jens-Otto Lassen * Jannik Lorenzen – Private Gram * Morten Hauch-Fausbøll – [[Major]] Fladsaa * Mikkel Trøst Bentzen – Private Nørreskov * Ari Alexander – Private Justesen * Mathias Lundkvist – Private Kolding * Jesper Hagelskær Paasch – Major Jepsen * Jan Jürgensen – Sergent Klostergaard * Simon Sears – [[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]] Holm * Jan Dose – Lieutenant-Colonel Becker * Jesper Hagelskær Paasch – Lieutenant Jepsen * Pelle Emil Hebsgaard – [[Runner (soldier)|Runner]] * [[Jan Dose]] - [[Oberleutnant]] Becker {{div col end}}
==Production== The film was directed by Roni Ezra and the screenplay was by Tobias Lindholm (who also wrote ''[[A Hijacking]]'', ''[[Borgen (TV series)|Borgen]]'' and ''[[The Hunt (2012 film)|The Hunt]]''). The outline story was based on eyewitness accounts, conversations and interviews with the few surviving veterans of 9 April 1940, who fought the invading German Army.<ref>{{cite web|last1=LINDEGAARD|first1=SIGNE HAAHR|title=For Gud, konge og fædreland|url=http://www.jyllands-posten.dk/premium/kultur/ECE6828213/for-gud-konge-og-faedreland/|website=Jyllands Posten|language=Danish}}</ref>
The "Between Schleswig Limits" museum in Bylderup-Bov was approached by [[Nordisk Film]] in the autumn of 2013 with regards to assisting with uniforms and weapons. In March 2014 the film company collected 120 [[Danish M1923 helmet|Danish steel helmets]], 100 gas-mask canisters, 50 pairs of wool pants, 24 dummy-rifles, 32 cartridge belts, and a khaki officer coat. Moreover, the museum loaned two old [[Nimbus (motorcycle)|Nimbus motorcycles]] with side-cars. All equipment was initially transported to Budapest in Hungary, where part of the movie was shot.<ref>{{cite web|title=Museet "Mellem Slesvigs Grænser" hjælper Nordisk Film|url=http://www.museum-rens.dk/186444928|website=Mellem Slesvigs Grænser|accessdate=27 February 2015|language=Danish}}</ref>
The film was also shot in Haderslev, where the streets around Møllepladsen, Sønderbro and Convent Cemetery was sealed off from 17 to 19 June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Conradsen|first1=Emilie|title=FILMOPTAGELSER BEGYNDER I HADERSLEV|url=http://www.tvsyd.dk/artikel/245228:Filmoptagelser-begynder-i-Haderslev|website=TV2 Syd|accessdate=27 February 2015|language=Danish}}</ref> Other shootings took place at the Jacob Michelsen's Farm in Aabenraa and in Søgårdlejren.
==Reception== The film received mixed, but generally favorable reviews from Danish critics, with [[Berlingske]] and Ekko giving it 5 out of 6 stars,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Lindberg|first1=Kristian|title=In 9. April Danish soldiers regains their honor|url=http://www.b.dk/film/i-9.-april-genvinder-danske-soldater-deres-aere|accessdate=11 December 2015|language=Danish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Michaëlis|first1=Bo Tao|title=Review of 9 April|url=http://www.ekkofilm.dk/anmeldelser/9-april/|accessdate=11 December 2015|language=Danish}}</ref> while others gave it between 2-5 out of 6 stars.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Skotte|first1=Kim|title=Danish movie showcases the horrors of war|url=http://politiken.dk/kultur/filmogtv/filmanmeldelser/ECE2583681/dansk-krigsfilm-vaerner-flot-om-den-voldsomme-virkelighed/|accessdate=11 December 2015|language=Danish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Ørsted|first1=Jacob|title=Danish war movie overshoot|url=http://ekstrabladet.dk/filmmagasinet/Filmanmeldelser/anmeldelse-dansk-krigsfilm-sigter-forgaeves-efter-spaending/5476932|accessdate=11 December 2015|language=Danish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Short chapter of the war made relevant|url=http://jyllands-posten.dk/kultur/film/ECE7537574/Anmeldere%3A+%229.+april%22+g%C3%B8r+kort+krigskapitel+relevant/|accessdate=11 December 2015|language=Danish}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{IMDb title|3542188|April 9th}} * {{rotten|9_april|April 9th}}
[[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:Danish films]] [[Category:Danish war films]] [[Category:Danish-language films]] [[Category:War drama films]] [[Category:World War II films]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films set in 1940]] [[Category:Films shot in Denmark]] [[Category:Screenplays by Tobias Lindholm]]

{{refimprove|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox medical condition | Name = Asystole | Image = Asystole11.JPG| Caption = A rhythm strip showing two beats of normal sinus rhythm followed by an atrial beat and asystole| synonyms = Beau's syndrome| pronounce = {{IPAc-en|ə|ˈ|s|ɪ|s|t|əl|iː}}| ICD10 = {{ICD10|I|46|0|i|40}} | ICD9 = {{ICD9|427.5}} | }} '''Asystole''' (1860, from Modern Latin, from Greek [[privative a]] "not, without" + ''systolē'' "contraction")<ref>{{OEtymD|asystole}}</ref><ref>{{LSJ|sustolh/|συστολή|ref}}.</ref> is the absence of ventricular contractions (note: this is in the context of a lethal [[heart arrhythmia]], not an induced asystole on a cooled patient on a [[heart-lung machine]] and [[general anesthesia]], during surgery necessitating stopping the heart). Asystole is the most serious form of [[cardiac arrest]] and is usually irreversible. A '''cardiac flatline''' is the state of total cessation of electrical activity from the [[heart]], which means no tissue contraction from the heart muscle and therefore no blood flow to the rest of the body.
Asystole should not be confused with very brief pauses in the heart's electrical activity—even those that produce a temporary flatline—that can occur in certain less severe abnormal rhythms. Asystole is different from very fine occurrences of [[ventricular fibrillation]], though both have a poor prognosis, and untreated fine VF will lead to asystole. Faulty wiring, disconnection of electrodes and leads, and power disruptions should be ruled out.
Asystolic patients (as opposed to those with a "shockable rhythm" such as ventricular fibrillation or [[ventricular tachycardia]], which can potentially be treated with [[defibrillation]]) usually present with a very poor prognosis. Asystole is found initially in only about 28% of cardiac arrest cases,<ref name=Bal2016>{{cite journal|last1=Baldzizhar|first1=A|last2=Manuylova|first2=E|last3=Marchenko|first3=R|last4=Kryvalap|first4=Y|last5=Carey|first5=MG|title=Ventricular Tachycardias: Characteristics and Management.|journal=Critical care nursing clinics of North America|date=September 2016|volume=28|issue=3|pages=317–29|pmid=27484660|doi=10.1016/j.cnc.2016.04.004}}</ref> but only 15% of these patients survive, even with the benefit of an [[intensive care unit]], with the rate being lower (6%) for those already prescribed drugs for [[vasopressor|high blood pressure]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kutsogiannis|first1=DJ|title=Survival after in-ICU PEA/asystole cardiac arrest unchanged at 20 yrs|journal=CMAJ|date=4 October 2011|url=http://pulmccm.org/main/2011/review-articles/survival-after-in-icu-cardiac-arrest-poor/}}</ref>
Asystole is treated by [[cardiopulmonary resuscitation]] (CPR) combined with an intravenous [[vasopressor]] such as [[epinephrine]] (a.k.a. adrenaline). Sometimes an underlying reversible cause can be detected and treated (the so-called "[[Hs and Ts]]", an example of which is [[hypokalaemia]]). Several interventions previously recommended—such as defibrillation (known to be ineffective on asystole, but previously performed in case the rhythm was actually very fine ventricular fibrillation) and intravenous [[atropine]]—are no longer part of the routine protocols recommended by most major international bodies.<ref>AHA Cardiac Recussitation Guidelines, 2010: http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/full/122/18_suppl_3/S729</ref> Asystole may be treated with 1 mg epinephrine by IV every 3–5 minutes as needed.
Survival rates in a cardiac arrest patient with asystole are much lower than a patient with a rhythm amenable to defibrillation; asystole is itself not a "shockable" rhythm. Out-of-hospital survival rates (even with emergency intervention) are less than 2 percent.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.lww.com/surveyanesthesiology/Citation/2008/10000/Medical_Futility_in_Asystolic_Out_of_Hospital.44.aspx|title=Medical Futility in Asystolic Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest|author=|date=1 October 2008|publisher=|journal=Survey of Anesthesiology|volume=52|issue=5|pages=261|accessdate=7 April 2018|via=journals.lww.com|doi=10.1097/01.SA.0000318635.97636.a6}}</ref>
==Cause== Possible underlying causes, which may be treatable and reversible in certain cases, include the [[Hs and Ts]].<ref name=ACLS_2003_H_T>{{cite book |author=Mazur G |title=ACLS: Principles And Practice |publisher=American Heart Assn |location=Dallas |year=2004 |pages=71–87 |isbn=0-87493-341-2 }}</ref><ref name=ACLS_2003_EP_HT>{{cite book |vauthors=Barnes TG, Cummins RO, Field J, Hazinski MF |title=ACLS for experienced providers |publisher=American Heart Assn |location=Dallas |year=2003 |pages=3–5 |isbn=0-87493-424-9 }}</ref><ref name="ECC_2005_7.2">{{cite journal |title=2005 American Heart Association Guidelines for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation and Emergency Cardiovascular Care - Part 7.2: Management of Cardiac Arrest. |journal=Circulation |volume=112 |issue=24 Suppl |pages=IV1–203 (7.2 IV58–66) |date=Dec 2005 |pmid=16314375 |doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.105.166550 |url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/content/full/112/24_suppl/IV-58 |author1= ECC Committee, Subcommittees and Task Forces of the American Heart Association}}</ref>
* [[Hypovolemia|'''H'''ypovolemia]] * [[Hypoxia (medical)|'''H'''ypoxia]] * [[Hydrogen|'''H'''ydrogen]] ions ([[acidosis]]) * [[Hypothermia|'''H'''ypothermia]] * [[Hyperkalemia|'''H'''yperkalemia]] or [[Hypokalemia|'''H'''ypokalemia]] * [[Hypoglycemia|'''H'''ypoglycemia]] * [[Tablet (pharmacy)|'''T'''ablets]] or [[Toxin|'''T'''oxin]]s ([[drug overdose]]) * [[electric shock|'''E'''lectric shock]] * [[Tachycardia|'''T'''achycardia]] * [[Cardiac tamponade|Cardiac '''T'''amponade]] * [[Tension pneumothorax|'''T'''ension pneumothorax]] * [[Thrombosis|'''T'''hrombosis]] ([[myocardial infarction]] or [[pulmonary embolism]]) * [[Physical trauma|'''T'''rauma]] ([[hypovolemia]] from blood loss)
While the heart is asystolic, there is no blood flow to the brain unless [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation|CPR]] or [[internal cardiac massage]] (when the chest is opened and the heart is manually compressed) is performed, and even then it is a small amount. After many emergency treatments have been applied but the heart is still unresponsive, it is time to consider pronouncing the patient [[dead]]. Even in the rare case that a rhythm reappears, if asystole has persisted for fifteen minutes or more, the brain will have been deprived of oxygen long enough to cause [[brain death]]. <gallery> Image:Lead II rhythm generated asystole.JPG|ECG lead showing asystole (flatline) File:Asystole.png|Asystole File:Asystole Coarse.png|Asystole coarse </gallery>
==See also== * [[Agonal heart rhythm]] * [[Ictal asystole]]
==References== <!-- ---------------------------------------------------------- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes for a discussion of different citation methods and how to generate footnotes using the <ref>,</ref> and <reference /> tags ----------------------------------------------------------- --> {{reflist}}

{{flagicon|São Paulo}} William Freire | manufacturer = | champion team = | tyres = [[Pirelli]] | current_season = 2013 Campeonato Sudamericano de GT season | website = {{URL|http://www.portalgt.com.br/}} }} '''Campeonato Sudamericano de GT''' (''Southamerican GT Championship'') previously known as '''GT3 Brasil Championship''', '''GT Brasil''' and '''Campeonato Brasileiro de GT''' was a [[sports car racing]] series based in the [[Brazil]] organized by the [[Stéphane Ratel Organisation|SRO Latin America]]. ==History== Starting in 2007, the GT3 Brasil Championship has been held in Brazil, also organized by SRO, with several veteran drivers racing in some events, such as former [[Formula One]] champions [[Emerson Fittipaldi]] and former [[Stock Car Brasil|Brazilian Stock Car]] champions [[Chico Serra]] and [[Ingo Hoffmann]]. Differently from the European series, GT3 Brasil accepts professional drivers, in a system where drivers are graded from A (International Driver) to D (Fully Amateur). In [[2010 GT Brasil season|2010]] the championship was renamed for GT Brasil and announced the creation of GT4 class. For 2012 season was introduce GT Premium class caters for older, such as the [[Dodge Viper|Dodge Viper Competition Coupe]] or [[Porsche 911 GT3#997 GT3|Porsche 997 GT3 Cup S]]. The category losing the primary sponsor and change their name to Campeonato Brasileiro de GT. In 2013 the series became a South American championship. ==Vehicles== [[File:GT3 Brasil Lamborghini Gallardo.jpg|220px|thumb|right|[[Lamborghini Gallardo]] driven by [[Ingo Hoffmann]] and Paulo Bonifácio in the gravel.]] The following chassis are currently in GT3 and GT Premium: * [[Audi R8 (road car)#R8 LMS|Audi R8 LMS ultra]] * [[Chevrolet Corvette (C6)#Z06-R|Corvette Z06-R GT3]] * [[Ferrari F430#F430 GT3|Ferrari F430 GT3]] * [[Lamborghini Gallardo|Lamborghini Gallardo LP520 GT3]] * [[Lamborghini Gallardo|Lamborghini Gallardo LP560 GT3]] * [[Lamborghini Gallardo|Lamborghini Gallardo LP600+ GT3]] * [[Porsche 911 GT3|Porsche 997 GT3 Cup S]] * [[Porsche 911 GT3|Porsche 991 GT3 Cup]] GT4: * [[Aston Martin Vantage (2005)#N24 and GT4|Aston Martin V8 Vantage GT4]] * [[Ferrari Challenge]] * [[Lotus Evora|Lotus Evora GT4]] * [[Maserati GranTurismo#GranTurismo MC (2009-)|Maserati GranTurismo MC]] ==Champions== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size: 95%;" ! revision.comment: Fix grammar
revision.text:
[[File:Redheffer machine.JPG|thumb|A diagram of Redheffer's first machine]] '''Charles Redheffer''' was an American [[inventor]] who claimed to have invented a [[perpetual motion]] machine. First appearing in [[Philadelphia]], Redheffer exhibited his machine to the public, charging high prices for viewing. When he applied to the government for more money, a group of inspectors were sent to examine the machine. It was discovered the machine was actually powered by a device Redheffer claimed was powered by the machine.
Redheffer moved to New York City and set up a similar [[scam]] after rebuilding his machine. However, an engineer detected that it was a fake by listening to its unsteady motions at an exhibition. He discovered that the machine was operated by a man using a crank in a room on the floor above. Redheffer returned to Philadelphia. He later claimed to have created another machine, but refused to demonstrate it to anyone. He managed to get a patent for his machine in 1820, but after this his fate is unknown.
==Personal life== Little has been recorded about Redheffer's life, other than his connection to the hoax. According to one source, he was from [[Germantown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Germantown]] in [[Philadelphia]],<ref>Weiss, p.35</ref> but most sources simply state that he appeared in Philadelphia with his machine. Redheffer disappeared from public view after the discovery of the fraud, and his fate is unknown.
==Appearance in Philadelphia== Charles Redheffer and his machine became well known in Philadelphia in 1812.<ref>Ord-Hume, p.125</ref> Redheffer claimed he had invented a [[perpetual motion]] machine and exhibited it in a house near the [[Schuylkill River]] in the outskirts of the city.<ref name=ordhume126>Ord-Hume, p.126</ref> He charged an admission fee of $5 (some sources claim $1) for men to view it; depending on the source, women were admitted free or at a charge of $1.<ref>Ord-Hume, p.130</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The Puzzle of Perpetual Motion |date=26 July 1954 |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]] |pages=8}}</ref> The machine caused a sensation, and Redheffer lobbied for funds to build a larger version.<ref name=ordhume126 />
On January 21, 1813, eight city commissioners visited Redheffer to inspect the machine. They had to do so through a barred window,<ref name=ordhume126 /> as Redheffer was concerned anyone going near the machine might damage it.<ref name=moh>{{cite web |url=http://www.museumofhoaxes.com/hoax/Hoaxipedia/Perpetual_Motion_Machine_of_Charles_Redheffer/ |title=Perpetual Motion Machine of Charles Redheffer |publisher=[[Museum of Hoaxes]] |accessdate=28 August 2009}}</ref> One of the inspectors, Nathan Sellers, was accompanied by his son Coleman, who noticed something odd about the [[gear]]s. The machine itself was said to be powering a separate device through a series of gears and weights. Coleman noticed that the cogs were worn on the wrong side and suggested that the device was in fact powering the machine.<ref name=ah>{{cite news |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/articles/magazine/ah/1961/3/1961_3_78.shtml |title=Why won’t they work? |first=Clifford B. |last=Hicks |date=April 1961 |work=[[American Heritage (magazine)|American Heritage Magazine]] |publisher=American Heritage Publishing Company |accessdate=28 August 2009}}</ref>
The elder Sellers was convinced the machine was a hoax. To validate his suspicions, he hired local engineer Isaiah Lukens to build a similar machine, using a hidden [[clockwork]] motor as a power source.<ref>Ord-Hume, p.127</ref> They then arranged a demonstration of the machine to Redheffer, who was immediately convinced and offered to buy it.<ref name=ah /> Meanwhile, Redheffer's machine appeared in the ''[[Philadelphia Gazette]]''. Civil engineer Charles Gobort offered to bet sums of money ranging from $6,000 to $10,000 that the machine was genuine, and that Redheffer had discovered perpetual motion.<ref name=ah />
==Move to New York City== [[File:Fulton.jpg|thumb|upright|Robert Fulton, who discovered that the machine exhibited in New York City was a fraud]] His ruse revealed, Redheffer immediately departed for New York City where he was still unknown.<ref name=moh /> He changed his machine somewhat so that it could not be detected as easily, and he exhibited it as he had done in Philadelphia.<ref>Ord-Hume, p.132</ref>
When mechanical engineer [[Robert Fulton]] went to see the machine, he noticed that the machine was unsteady as if someone were driving it manually and irregularly with a crank.<ref name=moh /> Fulton also detected that the sound was uneven, uncharacteristic of a machine's motions. He announced the machine was a fraud, and challenged Redheffer exclaiming he would expose the secret power source, otherwise he would pay for all the damage he would cause. Redheffer agreed, so Fulton removed some boards from the wall alongside the machine and exposed a [[catgut]] cord that led to the upper floor. Upstairs he found an old man who was turning a hand-crank with one hand and eating bread with the other. Spectators realized they had been duped and destroyed the machine; Redheffer fled the city.<ref name=ah />
==Later appearances== Redheffer appears to have constructed another machine in 1816, which he stated his intention to demonstrate to a group of men including the mayor and chief justice of Philadelphia. However, despite several meetings, Redheffer refused to demonstrate the machine to them.<ref>Ogden-Niles, p.26-27</ref>
On July 11, 1820, the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. Patent Office]] granted a [[patent]] to Charles Redheffer (or Charles Redheiffer) for a device listed as "machinery for the purpose of gaining power".<ref>Force, p.145</ref> (Unfortunately, all patents up to 1836 were lost in the [[1836 U.S. Patent Office fire]]. If recovered, it would be [[X-Patent]] X3,215.)
==Notes== {{Reflist|20em}}
==References== *{{cite book |title=A National Calendar ... Volume 2 |first=Peter |last=Force |publisher=Davis and Force |year=1821}} *{{cite book |title=Niles' weekly register, Volume 11 |first=William |last=Ogden Niles |publisher=[[Hezekiah Niles|H. Niles]] |year=1817}} *{{cite book |title=Perpetual Motion: The History of an Obsession |first=Arthur W. J. G. |last=Ord-Hume |publisher=Adventures Unlimited Press |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-931882-51-4}} *{{cite book |title=Thomas Say, early American naturalist |first=Harry B. |last=Weiss |author2=Ziegler, Grace M. |publisher=Ayer Publishing |year=1978 |isbn=978-0-405-10737-5}} {{Good article}}
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Redheffer, Charles}} [[Category:Hoaxes in science]] [[Category:Hoaxes in the United States]] [[Category:Perpetual motion]] [[Category:19th-century hoaxes]]
