revision.text:
{{Infobox song | name = Locked Up | cover = Akon - Locked Up - CD cover.jpg | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Akon]] | album = [[Trouble (Akon album)|Trouble]] | released = April 13, 2004 | format = {{hlist|[[CD single|CD]]|[[Music download|digital download]]}} | recorded = October 2003 | studio = | venue = | genre = {{hlist|[[Conscious hip hop]]|[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]}} | length = 3:56 | label = {{hlist|[[SRC Records|SRC]]|[[Universal Records (defunct record label)|Universal]]}} | writer = [[Akon]] | producer = [[Akon]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = [[Find Us]] | next_year = 2004 }} "'''Locked Up'''" is the debut single by American singer [[Akon]], taken as the lead single from his album, ''[[Trouble (Akon album)|Trouble]]''. The single was released in 2004, peaking at #8 on the [[Billboard Hot 100]]. Outside the United States, "Locked Up" peaked within the top 10 of the charts in the Republic of Ireland and the UK. ==Background== Although it was widely regarded that "[[Lonely (Akon song)|Lonely]]" offered the album's best option in terms of commercial breakthrough and lead single as well as 1st single, [[SRC Records|SRC]] A&R and producer [[Knobody]] chose "Locked Up" as the 1st and lead single because he wanted to break Akon in the streets 1st, and then cross-over. In an interview for [[HitQuarters]], he claimed: "Locked Up" is a street record. I thought that was the place for us to start to get a fan-base, knowing that weight. We thought really carefully about the record, what touches people and will get people's attention – so we added references of his kin and kith sending him magazines, money-orders, to visit him, ask where his lawyer is, accept his phone calls and ask "where're my niggaz on lockdown." The song was designed a breakout hit for Akon, something that could shape the future of his personal life and widely successful musical career. I worked on what I call "drops" – points in the record where it feels different, to break the monotony and make it a little more interesting."{{cite web |url=http://www.hitquarters.com/index.php3?page=intrview/opar/intrview_JeromeFoster.html |title=Interview With Knobody |publisher=[[HitQuarters]]|date=Sep 27, 2005 |accessdate=Jul 1, 2010}} Knobody produced an alternate of the song, featuring [[Styles P]], which appears as both a [[A-side and B-side|B-side]] on the single and as a bonus track on the UK version of the album. In 2004, [[T-Pain]] sampled the song in a parody recording "I'm Fucked Up", which became a main factor in him getting signed to [[Konvict Kartel]]. In 2005, the song was sampled in the track "Won't Let Me Out" by [[C-Murder]]. A music video was produced to promote the single. The video was directed by FlyyKai, and was edited to both the album version and the remix featuring Styles P. The French CD single also has a remix featuring [[French hip hop|French rapper]] [[Booba]], which is also Akon's favorite "Locked Up" remix{{Cite news|url=http://www.dhnet.be/medias/musique/je-represente-le-senegal-aux-etats-unis-51b7c599e4b0de6db98d276f|title=«Je représente le Sénégal aux Etats-Unis»|last=DH.be|first=|date=|work=DH.be|access-date=2017-10-19|language=fr|quote=Ma version préférée est celle avec Booba. (My favorite version is the one with Booba)}}. Another remix featuring Styles and British rapper Taz was included on the UK version of Trouble. ==Track listing== ; UK CD single # "Locked Up" – 3:56 # "Locked Up" (featuring Styles P) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Taz and Styles P) – 3:54 # "Locked Up" (Video) (featuring Taz and Styles P) – 3:54 ; UK 12" vinyl # "Locked Up" – 3:56 # "Locked Up" (featuring Styles P) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Taz and Styles P) – 3:54 # "Locked Up" (Instrumental) – 3:56 ; German CD single # "Locked Up" (featuring Azad) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (Without Rap) – 3:33 # "Locked Up" (featuring Styles P) – 3:50 # "Gunshot" – 2:56 ; UK promo single – The Global Remixeshttp://www.discogs.com/Akon-Locked-Up-Global-Remixes/release/555209 # "Locked Up" – 3:56 # "Locked Up" (featuring Styles P) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Taz and Styles P) – 3:56 # "Locked Up" (featuring Azad) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Savage) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Booba) – 3:50 # "Locked Up" (featuring Mayhem) – 4:22 # "Locked Up" (featuring Julio Voltio) – 3:50 ==Charts== {| class="wikitable" !Chart (2004–05) !Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Austria|64|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|Wallonia|26|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|France|12|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|Germany2|15|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up|id=6450}} |- {{singlechart|Ireland|10|week=9|year=2005}} |- {{singlechart|Dutch100|71|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|Spain|19|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|Switzerland|19|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up}} |- {{singlechart|UKchartstats|5|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up|songid=619}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|8|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up|artistid={{BillboardID|Akon}}}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardpopsongs|29|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up|artistid={{BillboardID|Akon}}}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrandbhiphop|6|artist=Akon|song=Locked Up|artistid={{BillboardID|Akon}}}} |} ==Certifications== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Country ! Provider ! Certification ! Sales |- | [[Brazil]] | [[Pro-Música Brasil|ABPD]] | Gold{{cite web|url=http://abpd.org.br/certificados_interna.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017195231/http://abpd.org.br/certificados_interna.asp |archivedate=2012-10-17 |df= }} | 50,000+ |- | [[United States]] | [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]] | Gold{{cite web|title=Gold & Platinum: Akon|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS&artist=Akon&format=&go=Search&perPage=50|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=May 22, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130225031458/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?table=SEARCH_RESULTS|archivedate=February 25, 2013|df=}} | 500,000+ |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{MetroLyrics song|akon|locked-up-remix}} {{Akon}} {{Styles P}} [[Category:Akon songs]] [[Category:2004 singles]] [[Category:Debut singles]] [[Category:Songs written by Akon]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Akon]] [[Category:2004 songs]] [[Category:Songs about prison]] [[Category:Songs critical of religion]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]] [[Category:Universal Music Group singles]] [[Category:SRC Records singles]]

revision.comment: /* Award Winners */
revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2012}} {{Kenyanfilmlist}} '''Lola Kenya Screen''', or '''Lola Kenya Children's Screen''' is an audio-visual media festival<ref name="uniceficdb">{{Cite news|url=http://uniceficdb.wordpress.com/2009/08/03/a-youth-film-festival-for-everyone/|title=A youth film festival for everyone|date=2009-08-03|work=UNICEF ICDB|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}}</ref> and learning-by-doing mentorship for children and youth in eastern Africa. It encompasses film production, film criticism, cultural journalism, media literacy, marketing, and event planning and organisation.<ref name="Cinema">Shohreh Jandaghian.(2007.07.18).'Lola Kenya Screen, The Only Children's Film Festival in Africa'. Cinema Without Borders. [http://cinemawithoutborders.com/festivals/1323-lola-kenya-screen-the-only-children-s-film-festival-in-africa.html http://cinemawithoutborders.com/festivals/1323-lola-kenya-screen-the-only-children-s-film-festival-in-africa.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref><ref name="Ogova">Jos Schuring. (2007.11.).'Ogova Ondego: Make children aware of the influence of film'. Kracht van Cultuur.[http://www.krachtvancultuur.nl/en/current/2007/november/ogova_ondego http://www.krachtvancultuur.nl/en/current/2007/november/ogova_ondego]. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref>
==Origins== Lola Kenya Screen was established in October 2005 by arts and culture practitioner Ogova Ondego,<ref name="Cinema"/> who has been its Managing Trustee and Creative Director since then.<ref name="sheffield">[http://sheffdocfest.com/speakers/view/3878]</ref><ref name="connestcp">[http://www.connectcp.org/profiles/profile.php?profileid=1937 http://www.connectcp.org/profiles/profile.php?profileid=1937]</ref><ref name="romediafoundation">{{Cite news|url=http://romediafoundation.wordpress.com/2011/10/17/barcelona-producers-of-the-world-unite/|title=BARCELONA – Producers of the World Unite|date=2011-10-17|work=ROMEDIA FOUNDATION|access-date=2018-09-06|language=en-US}}</ref> The name Lola Kenya Screen is [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] and means "see or watch films in Kenya".<ref name="Namibia">The Namibia Economist. (2011.08.25)."Namibia: Local Youth Organisation Shines in Kenya". Allafrica.com. [http://allafrica.com/stories/201108251165.html http://allafrica.com/stories/201108251165.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref> Lola Kenya Screen aims to seek, identify, nurture and promote creative talent among children and youth through hands-on skills development programmes in areas such as journalism, film-making, arts appreciation, and organisation and presentation of cultural and creative events. <ref name="Cinema"/><ref name="Lights"/><ref name="Craig">Craig Kimu. A Journey to Remember (2008.08.).Art Moves Africa. [http://www.artmovesafrica.org/index.php?id=299 http://www.artmovesafrica.org/index.php?id=299]. retrieved 2012.01.11.</ref><ref>[http://ombetja.org/index.php/archive/32-archived/82-a-crack-in-the-wall]. retrieved 2013.03.09.</ref>
==Objectives== The Memorandum and Articles of Association of Lola Kenya Screen are in Chapter 486 of the Laws of Kenya, under which Lola Kenya Screen is incorporated. Its main objectives are:<ref>https://groups.yahoo.com/group/themagic_network/message/4790</ref><ref>http://www.nairobiliving.com/component/content/article/15-presscentre/320-lola-kenya-screen-2009-invitation.html?directory=1</ref><ref name="artmatters.info/?page_id=163">artmatters.info/?page_id=163</ref><ref name="digicastmagazine.com">http://digicastmagazine.com/issue/november-2011/article/lola-kenya-screen-calls-for-entries</ref> *To make the means of film production accessible to emerging talents; *To build an audience for African films by encouraging culturally relevant, audience-sensitive films in local languages, cultures and reality; *To promote film skills and develop talent in Kenya; *To produce at least six films each year from film production workshops; *To collaborate with national and international partners in the training of young talents who wish to further their expertise in screenplay writing, cinematography, art department, sound, acting, directing, and producing.
==Programmes==
===Skills Development=== During the festival, children and youth serve on the film selection committee, programme preparation and presentation (Master of Ceremonies, MC), film jury, festival press (cultural journalism), and in the film-making workshop, which produces at least five short films for children and youth.<ref name="Taking">TakingITGlobal. [http://orgs.tigweb.org/lola-kenya-screen http://orgs.tigweb.org/lola-kenya-screen]. Retrieved 2012.01.19</ref> *The Festival Press programme aims to raise the standards of creative and cultural journalism in eastern Africa. *The Production Workshop seeks to equip children and youth with the skills to make films. *The Programme Organisation and Presentation (MC) programme mentors participants in the organisation and presentation of events and programmes. *The Film Jury enables participants to develop critical appreciation of creative work in general and film in particular. The jury members, all of whom are children and youth, watch films and assign awards.<ref name="Taking"/> * The Media Literacy programme develops understanding of the opportunities and dangers inherent in modern mass media and how to avoid problems by informed participation.
Since August 2006, when Lola Kenya Screen opened her doors to the first group of participants, some 254 children and youth had by December 2011 passed through her.
===Other programmes=== ;Marketing This is the platform on which various stakeholders network, publicise and market values, products and services targeting children, youth and family during the festival. Docs for Kids, a programme for trainers of trainers of makers of documentary films for children and youth, and IPO-Eastern Africa, for instance, were launched here.<ref name="UNESCO">UNESCO (2009.08.13). UNESCO supports Independent Producers Forum in East Africa. [http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=29049&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html http://portal.unesco.org/ci/en/ev.php-URL_ID=29049&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.19</ref> This is also the entry point for international productions into eastern Africa, as many of the international films exhibited here are unlikely to be shown anywhere else in Africa, which has hardly any market for children and youth films.
;Schools outreach Lola Kenya Screen showcases films in educational institutions in and around Nairobi and helps to make pupils and students aware of the importance of mass media in modern societies.<ref name="AdminCMK">Administrator. (2010.12.28). ComMattersKenya-Supported Mentorship Programme Comes of Age. [http://www.commatterskenya.com/component/content/article/1-latest-news/108-commatterskenya-supported-mentorship-programme-comes-of-age.html http://www.commatterskenya.com/component/content/article/1-latest-news/108-commatterskenya-supported-mentorship-programme-comes-of-age.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.20.</ref>
;Community screening and mobile cinema Lola Kenya Screen collaborates with various partners to show films, conduct workshops and host seminars in communities in Nairobi and its environs. One such partner is Slum-TV, with whom Lola Kenya Screen reaches out to the public in the slums of [[Mathare]], [[Huruma]], [[Jericho, Nairobi|Jericho]] and [[Kibera]].<ref name=com_scrng>'Community Film Screening Campaign Targets Residents of Nairobi City's Mathare Valley'. [http://www.cinetoile.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=40&Itemid=18&lang=en http://www.cinetoile.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=40&Itemid=18&lang=en]. Retrieved 2012.02.01</ref>
;Lola Kenya Screen film forum This is a monthly showcase of films from eastern Africa<ref name="Goethe">Goethe. Art and Film: Lola Kenya Screen Film Forum [http://www.goethe.de/ins/ke/nai/kul/mag/kuf/en7113177.htm]. Retrieved 2012.08.14</ref><ref name="Eventcalendar">Eventcalendar. Event Calendar: Lola Kenya Screen Film Forum [http://www.goethe.de/ins/ke/nai/ver/en9575419v.htm]. Retrieved 2012.08.14</ref><ref name="EventsinAfrica">EventsinAfrica. Events in Africa:What's on in Nairobi [http://nairobi.wantedinafrica.com/whats-on/17499/lola-kenya-screen-forum-on-short-films-from-eastern-africa.html]. Retrieved 2012.08.14</ref> that has been held since December 15, 2005. Held on the last Monday of every month at the [[Goethe-Institut]] in Nairobi, the forum is a gathering of film students, filmmakers, film journalists, producers, art directors and others. Films are screened and participants hold discussions and explore other initiatives to advance film-making in the region [http://chicamod.com/entertainment/movies/579-lola-kenya-screen-film-forum].
==Film festival== The annual Lola Kenya Screen film festival takes place in the first full week of August. Since 2008 it has also hosted the Kids For Kids Festival-Africa (KFKF-A) competition for films made by children for children across Africa.<ref name="Beth"/>
The film festival focuses on films by children and youth, films by students, amateurs and professionals for children and youth, and films involving children and youth.<ref name="David"/> During the festival, children (6- to 13-year-olds) and youth (14- to 25-year-olds) serve on the film selection committee, on the film jury, in programme preparation and presentation (MC), in the festival press (creative journalism), and in the practical film-making workshop that produces at least five short films for children and youth.<ref name="Cinema"/><ref name="Ogova"/><ref name="Lights"/>
The festival exhibits the best possible films, both local and international, for children, youth and family.<ref name="First">"Young Filmmakers in Kenya, Africa at First Light". First Light Movies. [http://www.firstlightonline.co.uk/make-a-film/step-4/international-links/young-filmmakers-in-nairobi-kenya-africa/ http://www.firstlightonline.co.uk/make-a-film/step-4/international-links/young-filmmakers-in-nairobi-kenya-africa/]. Accessed 2012.01.04</ref> It showcases films in all kinds of formats, categories and genres: short films; long films; children's and youth films; animation; African films; experimental films; creatively packaged music videos; television series and programmes; feature films; documentary films; public service announcements and commercials; student films; and computer games.<ref name="filmcont">[http://filmcontests.reelshowint.com/international-student-film-festival-directory-2012/student-film-festivals-kenya/#FSContact3 http://filmcontests.reelshowint.com/international-student-film-festival-directory-2012/student-film-festivals-kenya/#FSContact3]</ref>
===Details=== During the inaugural event in 2006, participants under the guidance of Antonia Ringbom of Finland made a compilation of nine short cartoons that won the Africa Grand Prize for achievement in a film made by children at the 5th World Summit on Media for Children in Johannesburg, South Africa, in 2007.<ref name="Kenyan">Christelle De Jager. (2007.04.04)."Kenyan kids cartoons win Summit: Children's films win Africa Grand Prize". Variety. [http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117962519/ http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117962519/]. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref> In 2007 and 2008, children and youth under the guidance of Finnish Maikki Kantola, Egyptian Abdel Latif, and Dutch Duco Tellegen made 14 films and 3 songs that were showcased all over the world and won several accolades and awards: the 2nd Kids For Kids Festival Africa Competition grand prize in 2008; the Special Jury Prize at 17th Jugend Medien Festival in Berlin in 2008; represented Africa at the global Kids For Kids Festival Competition in 2008; nominated for Best Animation at the 5th Africa Movie Academy Awards in 2009; and nominated for Best Short Documentary at the 5th Africa Movie Academy Awards in 2009.<ref name="Lights">[http://www.kenyabuzz.com/lifestyle/lights-camera-action-helping-children-take-control Clar] Ni Chonghaile. (2011.07.)"Lights, Camera, Lights! Helping children Take Control of Their Destinies". Kenya Buzz<nowiki/>http://www.kenyabuzz.com/lifestyle/lights-camera-action-helping-children-take-control. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref><ref name="AMAA">Editor. (2009.04.03). 'AMAA 2009: Artistes at War'. Modern Ghana.[http://www.modernghana.com/movie/4465/3/amaa-2009-artistes-at-war.html http://www.modernghana.com/movie/4465/3/amaa-2009-artistes-at-war.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.01.</ref> These films are still on the festival circuit around the world.<ref name="David"/>
==Achievements== Between August 2006 and December 2011, Lola Kenya Screen has trained 254 children and youth from Kenya, Uganda, Rwanda, Zanzibar, Tanzania and Zimbabwe in media skills and 6 adults in making documentaries for children and youth.<ref name="Lights"/> Its mentorship programme has produced more than 30 films since 2006, including several that have won awards and accolades on the international film circuit.<ref name="Lights">[http://cms.privatelabel.co.za/pls/cms/iac.page?p_t1=2245&p_t2=0&p_t3=0&p_t4=0&p_dynamic=YP&p_content_id=154627&p_site_id=113]. Retrieved 2013.03.09</ref> In 2011, ''Happy Times'' by Elaine Nesbitt and ''Manani Ogres'' by Samuel Musembi, Joseph Hongo, Marcus Kang’ethe and Norrick Mwangi were selected to take part in the sixth Busan International Kids' Film Festival in South Korea.<ref name="Lights"/>[http://cms.privatelabel.co.za/pls/cms/iac.page?p_t1=2245&p_t2=0&p_t3=0&p_t4=0&p_dynamic=YP&p_content_id=154627&p_site_id=113]
Lola Kenya Screen 2008 attracted participation from Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, and Zimbabwe,<ref name="Sharon">Sharon F. Mazvihwa. Participation in Lola Screen Festival. (2008.08.). ArtMoves Africa. [http://www.artmovesafrica.org/index.php?id=298 http://www.artmovesafrica.org/index.php?id=298]. Retrieved 2012.01.11</ref> and films from 56 countries were shown.<ref name="Craig"/> Between 2006 and 2011, Lola Kenya Screen has showcased more than 1950 films from 102 countries.<ref name="Lights"/>
==Awards== The Lola Kenya Screen festival comprises several film exhibition sections.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://film.britishcouncil.org/lola-kenya-screen|title=British Council Film: Lola Kenya Screen|last=Film|first=British Council|website=film.britishcouncil.org|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref>http://filmcontests.reelshowint.com/international-student-film-festival-directory-2012/student-film-festivals-kenya/</ref> The main film prizes are the Golden Mboni Award for the best children's film and the 14-Plus Award for the best youth film.<ref>http://www.the-star.co.ke/word-is/word-is/59617-lola-kenya-screen-calls-for-entries</ref> Other prizes include the Most Creative Project, Children's Rights, Best Animation, Best Documentary, Best Fiction, Best Experimental Film, Best Student Film, Best Kenyan Film, and Best Eastern Africa Film.<ref>http://www.screenafrica.com/page/news/africa/1202940-Lola-Kenya-Screen-calls-for-participation</ref><ref name="artmatters.info/?page_id=163"/><ref name="digicastmagazine.com"/>
==Award Winners== Winners of the Golden Mboni prize for the best children’s films have included Dutch Mischa Kamp's ''Tony 10'' (2012),<ref name="Das Geheimer Zimmer">{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/LolaKenyaScreen|title=Lola Kenya Screen film festival|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Belgian Vincent Bruno’s ''Le Maillot de Cristiano'' (''Cristiano Ronaldo's Shirt'', 2011),<ref name="Le Maillot">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediawavefestival.hu/index.php?modul=filmek&kod=6341&nyelv=eng|title=Filmek - www.mediawavefestival.hu|website=www.mediawavefestival.hu|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Nigerian Mak Kusare’s ''Champions of Our Time'' (2010),<ref name="nairaland">{{Cite web|url=http://www.nairaland.com/nigeria/topic-566995.0.html|title=Lagos State Sponsored Movie Champions Of Our Time Wins Top Awards - TV/Movies - Nigeria|website=www.nairaland.com|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref name="supplemag">{{Cite web|url=http://www.supplemagazine.org/champions-of-our-time-wins-multiple-awards.html|title=Supple Magazine » Champions of Our Time wins multiple awards|website=www.supplemagazine.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Italian Marco Gianfreda’s ''Io Parlo'' (''I'll Tell on You'', 2009),<ref name="scrnafrica">[http://www.screenafrica.com/news/africa/239821.htm http://www.screenafrica.com/news/africa/239821.htm]</ref> Swedish Peter Naess’s ''Hoppet'' (''Leaps and Bounds'', 2008),<ref name="3rd_LKS">3rd Lola Kenya Screen Unveils Winning Films – Swedish film wins 3rd place in children’s film competition. Balancing Act Africa. [http://www.balancingact-africa.com/news/broadcast/issue-no36/distribution/3rd-lola-kenya-scree/bc http://www.balancingact-africa.com/news/broadcast/issue-no36/distribution/3rd-lola-kenya-scree/bc]</ref> Israeli Itai Lev’s ''Giborim Kitanin'' (2007),<ref name="noa">[http://www.noa-international.com/59208/Little-Heroes http://www.noa-international.com/59208/Little-Heroes]</ref> and Ukrainian Koval Stepan’s ''Zlydni'' (2006).<ref name="lks_41867">{{Cite web|url=http://www.lolakenyascreen.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=122&Itemid=81|title=Lola Kenya Screen – Keeping Films for Children and Youth in Focus|website=www.lolakenyascreen.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref>
Winners of the 14-Plus Award for the best youth film, a prize introduced in 2009 out of recognition that the festival was growing and catered to both children and youth, are German Daniel Hedfeld and René Sydow's ''Das Geheimer Zimmer''(''Secret Room'', 2012),<ref name="Das Geheimer Zimmer"/><ref name="Das Geheimer">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dgz-derfilm.de/14-award-fur-den-besten-internationalen-jugendfilm/|title=14+ Award für den Besten Internationalen Jugendfilm|last=Zimmer|first=Das geheime|website=www.dgz-derfilm.de|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Madagascan Mamihasina Raminosoa and Andriamanisa Radoniaina’s ''Dzaomalaza et le Saphir Bleu'' (''Dzaomalaza and the Blue Sapphire'', 2011),<ref name="Dzao">[http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/201108220731.html http://fr.allafrica.com/stories/201108220731.html]</ref> Malawian Charles Shemu Joyah’s ''Seasons of a Life'' (2010),<ref name="ombetja">[http://ombetja.org/Prize.html http://ombetja.org/Prize.html]</ref> and South African Minky Schlesinger’s ''Ugugu no Andile'' (Gugu and Andile, 2009).<ref name="scrnafrica"/><ref name="Gugu no Andile">{{Cite web|url=http://www.gautengfilm.org.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=538:gugu-a-andile-wins-another-award&catid=72:september&Itemid=109|title=Gugu & Andile wins another award|website=www.gautengfilm.org.za|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref>
The Best Animation Award has gone to ''Gamba Trista'' (Loser Leg) by Francesco Filippi of Italy (2011),<ref name="cineitalia">{{Cite web|url=http://www.cinemaitaliano.info/news/09052/pizzangrillo-gamba-trista-e-paradiso-premiati.html|title="Pizzangrillo", "Gamba Trista" e "Paradiso" premiati al Lola Kenya Screen Festival 2011 - CinemaItaliano.info|website=www.cinemaitaliano.info|language=it|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> ''Lost and Found'' by Philip Hunt of the United Kingdom (2010),<ref name="vimeo">[http://vimeopro.com/studioaka/lost-and-found http://vimeopro.com/studioaka/lost-and-found]</ref> which also won the Silver Mboni Award for the second best children's film<ref name="studioaka">[http://studioaka.squarespace.com/awards/ http://studioaka.squarespace.com/awards/]</ref> and the Audience's Choice Award,<ref name="vimeo"/> ''Zlamana Pieczpc'' (''The Broken Seal'') by Pawel Czarzasty of Poland (2009),<ref name="lks_41867"/> ''Max's Words'' by Galen Fott and Jerry Hunt of the United States (2008),<ref name="bigfott">{{Cite web|url=http://bigfott.com/Max.html|title=Max's Words|website=bigfott.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> and ''More, Strycku, and Proc Je Slane?'' (''The Sea, Uncle, Why Is It Salty?'') by Jan Balej of the Czech Republic (2007).<ref name="icms">[http://icms.iac.iafrica.com/pls/cms/iac.page?p_t1=2054&p_t2=4718&p_t3=0&p_t4=0&p_dynamic=YP&p_content_id=402709&p_site_id=103 http://icms.iac.iafrica.com/pls/cms/iac.page?p_t1=2054&p_t2=4718&p_t3=0&p_t4=0&p_dynamic=YP&p_content_id=402709&p_site_id=103]</ref>
''Zlamana Pieczpc'' by Pawel Czarzasty and ''Ksiezycowa Kraina'' (''Lunar Land'') by Andrzej Kukula, both of Poland, won the Best TV Series Award and the Best Animation Film Award, respectively, in 2009.<ref name="tvsfa">{{Cite web|url=http://tvsfa.com/index.php/mis-fantazy/?lang=en|title=Fantazy the Bear – TV Studio Filmów Animowanych sp. z o.o.|website=tvsfa.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref> Another Polish production, ''Magiczne Drzewo'' (The Magic Tree) by Andrzej Maleszka won the 2010 Best TV Series Award.
Winners of the Best Student Film Award have included ''Znikniecie''(''Vanishing'', 2012) by Bartosz Kruhlik',<ref name="Das Geheimer Zimmer"/>'Jutro'' (''Tomorrow'') by Bartosz Kruhlik of Poland (2011), ''Great Expectations'' by Alexei Gubenco of Romania (2010), ''Elephants'' by Sally Pearce of the United Kingdom (2009), and ''Vika'' by Tsivia Barkai of Israel (2006).
Among others, the Best Documentary Film Award has gone to ''Paradiso'' by Italian Alessandro Negrini, working in Northern Ireland (2011),<ref name="cineitalia"/> ''Big Sister Punam'' by Serbian Lucian and Natasa Muntean (2010),<ref name="goingplaces">[http://www.goingplacessa.co.za/article_detail.asp?Article_ID=2253&Article_Year=2010 http://www.goingplacessa.co.za/article_detail.asp?Article_ID=2253&Article_Year=2010]</ref> ''A Beautiful Tragedy'' by Norway-based David Kinsella of the UK (2009), which also took the 14-Plus Award for the second best youth film,<ref name="scrnafrica"/> and ''Journey of a Red Fridge'' by Lucian Muntean and Natasa Stankovic of Serbia (2008).<ref name="Red_Fridge">Journey of A Red Fridge wins best documentary award. [http://www.esodoc.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48:journery-of-a-red-fridge&catid=17&Itemid=51 http://www.esodoc.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=48:journery-of-a-red-fridge&catid=17&Itemid=51]</ref>
Other winners have included Polish Wojciech Nowak's ''Przebunie.txt'' (''Awakening'')(Most Experimental Film Award, 2012),<ref name="Das Geheimer Zimmer"/> Kenyan Kwame Nyong’o's ''The Legend of Ngong Hills'' (Best Eastern African Film Award, 2012),<ref name="Das Geheimer Zimmer"/> Spanish Jose y Cesar Esteban Alenda's ''Matara A Un Nino'' (''The Child will Die'') (Best Short Film Award, 2012)<ref http://www.screenqueensland.com.au/index.php?option=com_mtree&task=att_download&link_id=118&cf_id=24]</ref> ''Zebu and the Photofish'' by Kenyan Zipporah Nyaruri (Best Kenyan Film, 2011), web|url=http://www.german-films.de/filmarchive/browse-archive/?film_id=1844&pos=40&query=v&mode=filmarchive&tx_moviedb_pi2%5Bview%5D=detail&cHash=ea02d672ffc4c890dc96785fba9e8f62|title=German Films: Gili Dolev (Silver Mboni Award for the second best children's film, 2009),<ref name="happy">[http://www.happyduckling.com/ http://www.happyduckling.com/]</ref> ''Winning Streak'' by Marc de Launay of the United Kingdom (Silver Mboni Award for the second best children's film, 2006),<ref name="mandra">{{Cite by Caroline Kamya of Uganda (Best Eastern Africa Film, 2007), ''Kibera Kid'' by Kenya-based Nathan Collett of the United States (Best Kenyan Children's Film, 2006), and ''We Were Young'' by Philippe Talavera of Namibia (14-Plus Award for the Second Best Youth Film, 2010).<ref name="ombetja"/>
Spanish films dominated the awards list in the 6th Lola Kenya Screen in 2011. The Silver Mboni for the second best children’s film went to ''Pizzangrillo'' (''Lighthearted Boy'') by Marco Gianfreda of Italy, and the Bronze Mboni for the third best children’s film went to ''Volterata'' (''Somersault'') by Alex Morante of Spain, which also won the Most Experimental Film prize. ''La Playa de Berlin'' (''Cannon Beach'') by Manuel Calvo of Spain won the 14-Plus Award for the second best youth film, and ''Mi Otra Mitad'' (''My Other Half'') by Beatriz Sanchis, also of Spain, took the 14-Plus Award for the third best youth film. Other winners included ''Mute'' by Muayad Alayan of Palestine (Best Children’s Rights Film). The Ombetja Yehinga Organisation headed by Philippe Talavera of Namibia wone a Special Youth Prize for their three films ''Sex and Chocolate'', ''Teddy Bear Love'' and ''Make a Move''.<ref name="Selma_Ikela">Selma Ikela (2011.08.19). "Namibian films clean up against 250 competitors". Namibian Sun. [http://www.sun.com.na/content/local-news/namibian-films-clean-against-250-competitors http://www.sun.com.na/content/local-news/namibian-films-clean-against-250-competitors]. Retrieved 2012.01.27.</ref> The 14-Plus Award Special Commendation went to ''Bizzaire'' by Kenyan Martin Ndichu. Serbians Lucian and Natasa Muntean received the Best Documentary Special Commendation award for ''Mbaabu and the Mountains of the Moon''. The 5th Kids for Kids Festival Africa Prize was shared by Kenyan productions ''Monsters of the New Age'' by Brian Saruni and ''Vanessa's Dream'' by Adede Hawi and Daki Mohammed.
==Facilitators, Mentors and Resource People== Some of the specialists who have mentored children and youth at Lola Kenya Screen have included Antonia Ringbom of Finland/Sweden(Animation film production, 2006), Maikki Kantola of Finland (Animation film production, 2007), Eid Abdel Latif of Egypt (Animation film production, 2008), Duco Tellegen and Meike Statema of The Netherlands (Documentary filmmaking for children and youth, 2008),<ref name="Lolakids&">Lola Kids & Docs Workshop in Kenya (2008). [http://www.idfa.nl/industry/Festival/latest-news/archive/2008/news/lola-kids-docs-workshop-in-kenya.aspx http://www.idfa.nl/industry/Festival/latest-news/archive/2008/news/lola-kids-docs-workshop-in-kenya.aspx]. Retrieved 2012.01.20</ref> Anette Tony Hansen of Denmark (Television drama for children and youth, 2009), Signe Zeilich-Jensen (Film judging, 2008),<ref name="Sharon"/> Fina Sensada-Boixader of Spain (Documentary filmmaking, 2009), Rut Gomez Sobrino of Spain (Journalism, 2009), Florence Sipalla of Kenya (Programme planning, 2008), and Kenyans Cajetan Boy (Film scripting, 2011) and Ogova Ondego (cultural journalism, creative writing, critical appreciation of creativity, film judging, media literacy, programme planning, 2006-2011).<ref name="Craig"/><ref name="Sharon"/>
Other facilitators have included David Kinsella of Norway (Film editing, 2008), Emily Wanja, Wanjiru Kairu and Vincho Nchogu of Kenya (Documentary filmmaking, 2009), and Allan Aligula of Kenya (Documentary filmmaking, 2010).
Motivational guest speakers on film-making have included Kenyan Judy Kibinge, Wanuri Kahiu, Guy Wilson, Ali Mwangola and Belgian Aurelien Bodinaux (2010).
The festival has also been attended by film producer Aurelien Bodinaux of Belgium (2009, 2010), TV producer Elahe Kasmaei of Iran (2008), afro-fusion musician Joel Sebunjo of Uganda (2006–2009) and independent filmmakers Aster Bedane of Ethiopia (2009), Ashraf Simwogerere Mayanja of Uganda (2009), Caroline Kamya of Uganda (2007), Sheila Mulinya of Kenya (2006, 2008, 2009, 2011), Katrin Ender of Germany (2006), Susan Wamburi of Kenya (2006, 2011) and Runcie Chidebe of Nigeria (2009), Kenyan screen actresses Nice Githinji and Janet Kirina (2008), and Fr Pietro Caggiano of Italy (2009, 2011).
==Partnerships== Lola Kenya Screen, a Nairobi-based charity,<ref name="David">David Odongo.2011.01.13.'Boon for children, youth filmmakers'. The Standard. [http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/archives/arts/InsidePage.php?id=2000026682&cid=291&story=Boon%20for%20children,%20youth%20filmmakers http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/archives/arts/InsidePage.php?id=2000026682&cid=291&story=Boon%20for%20children,%20youth%20filmmakers].Accessed 2012.01.04</ref> is a member of the International Centre of Cinema for Children and Young People (CIFEJ), an organisation founded in 1955 under the auspices of UNESCO and UNICEF to promote excellence in cinema for children and youth, and of the Kids For Kids Festival (KFKF) community of filmmakers and educators, which promotes audiovisual media content created by children for children.<ref name="Lights"/> To implement its programmes, Lola Kenya Screen has worked with the Goethe-Institut in Kenya, the [[Danish Film Institute]], Prix Jeunesse of Germany, Africalia of Belgium, the Jan Vrijman Fund of the International Documentary Festival Amsterdam (IDFA) of The Netherlands, [[UNESCO]], the Prince Claus Fund for Culture and Development of the Netherlands, and ComMattersKenya and ArtMatters. Info of Kenya. The partnership with UNESCO<ref name="UNESCO"/> enabled Lola Kenya Screen to host the first film summit for independent television and audiovisual media content producers in eastern Africa, which gave birth to the Nairobi Declaration and IPO-Eastern Africa network of audiovisual media and Television producers in the [[Great Lakes region|Great Lakes]] and [[Horn of Africa]] regions.<ref name="Beth">Bethsheba Achitsa.2011.06.27.'Lola Kenya is Back'.Africa Review. [http://www.africareview.com/Arts+and+Culture/Lola+Kenya+festival+screen/-/979194/1189874/-/view/printVersion/-/2d4xlyz/-/index.html http://www.africareview.com/Arts+and+Culture/Lola+Kenya+festival+screen/-/979194/1189874/-/view/printVersion/-/2d4xlyz/-/index.html]. Retrieved 2012.01.04</ref> The collaboration with Africalia produced a network of film festivals in Africa that bring African cinema to Africans.<ref name="cineto_ile">[http://www.cinetoile.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21&lang=en http://www.cinetoile.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21&lang=en]</ref> This arrangement, called Cinetoile and funded by the European Commission and the Belgian Development Cooperation in 2010, helped strengthen Lola Kenya Screen's school and neighbourhood film screening outreach programme.
==References== [http://www.medianigeria.com/30686/massive-fire-shuts-down-nairobi-airport-kenya/ Don't forget that Lola Kenya Screen was established in October 2005] <references />
==External links== *http://www.goethe.de/ins/ke/nai/kul/mag/kuf/en7113177.htm *http://www.comminit.com/content/lola-kenya-screen *http://allafrica.com/stories/201210190059.html *http://equator2012.blogspot.com/2012/12/lola-film-screen-at-german-cultural.html *http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/article-32854/lola-kenya-screen-calls-entries *http://www.lolakenyascreen.org *http://www.artmatters.info/ *http://www.commatterskenya.com *http://www.kidsforkidsfestival.org/en/index.htm *http://www.screenafrica.com/news/festivals/156942.htm *https://www.facebook.com/LolaKenyaScreen *http://portal.unesco.org/culture/en/ev.php-URL_ID=38563&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html *http://www.cinetoile.eu/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=4&lang=en *http://dailykenya.blogspot.com/2013/01/calls-for-application-8th-lola-kenya.html *http://filmkenya.blogspot.com/2011/02/43rd-lola-kenya-screen-film-forum-lksff.html *http://www.kimpavitapress.no/blog/2012/07/08/57th-lola-kenya-screen-film-forum-wows-participants-with-childrens-creativity-by-daisy-nandeche-okoti/ *https://www.flickr.com/photos/lolakenyascreen/ *https://www.youtube.com/user/Lolakenyascreen *http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/lifestyle/2009/08/05/looking-forward-to-the-th-lola-kenya-screen/ *http://www.thecallsheet.co.za/daily_news/view/2785 *http://www.animationsa.org/community/press-releases/liezel/lola-kenya-screen *http://nfvf.co.za/article/sa-italy-france-and-tanzania-win-big-at-lola-kenya-screen *http://zuqka.com/event/lola-kenya-screen-film-festival/ *http://www.mambomagazine.com/in-deep/arts-and-culture/childrens-voices-heard-through-cinema *http://www.ghafla.co.ke/news/movies/item/1725-insightful-56th-lola-kenya-film-forum-held *https://www.blogcatalog.com/topic/lola+kenya+screen/ {{-}}

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=October 2017}} {{self-published|date=October 2017}} {{overly detailed|date=October 2017}} }}
{{Infobox music festival | name =Netmage | image =Netmage musician.jpg | caption = | location =[[Bologna]], [[Italy]] | years_active =2000–present | founders =[http://www.xing.it/ XING] | dates = | genre = [[Electronic music]], | attendance = | capacity = | website =[http://www.netmage.it/ Netmage] }} '''Netmage'''<ref>[http://www.netmage.it/ Netmage]</ref> is an international festival dedicated to electronic art curated by Xing<ref>[http://www.xing.it/ XING]</ref> and produced annually—in the city of [[Bologna]]—as a multidisciplinary program of works, investigating and promoting contemporary audiovisual research. The festival was born in 2000 with funds provided by the [[European Union]], when Bologna represented one of the nine major [[European capital of culture]]. The festival concentrates on an amalgam of Happenings, environments, and audio/visual installations, it does through a concentration on creative scenes<ref>[http://arted.osu.edu/publications/pdf_files/paper38.pdf The creative Scene in Milano] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704051720/http://arted.osu.edu/publications/pdf_files/paper38.pdf |date=2008-07-04 }}</ref> and subcultural communities.<ref>[http://www.ibiblio.org/squealer/butchhome/Ch_Scene/ch_scene_communication.htm CH-Scene: Communication Theories and Musical Communities by Butch Lazorchak]</ref>
The experience of Netmage (eleven editions from 2001 to 2011) was merged into the annual [[Live Arts Week]].
==Mission== The mission of Netmage is to investigate the relationship between the "liveness" and the "ambient space". At the crossroads of these two terms is situated the notion of "post-cinema": defined as an environmental construction capable of gathering widely diverse attitudes in a public space. <ref name="popularFilm">{{cite book |title=Memory and Popular Film: Inside Popular Film| first="Jeffrey"| last="Pence" |editor="Paul Grainge"|publisher="Manchester UP"|year=2003}}</ref> Post Cinema/Postmemory It is a cinema made of multi-projections on a number of screens with no seating, a multiplication of narrative traces, possible points of view, physical positions of the spectators; achieving a removal of the forced estrangement of the 20th Century spectator (the darkness of the room, physical and perceptive isolation, a monodirectional viewing perspective) that evoke the world of the first [[Happenings]] of the 1960s, the philosophy of [[expanded cinema]], and successive multimedia installation experiments of the 1980s.
=="Live Media"==
"[[Live Media]] is an open-ended term which has come into currency amongst artists and theoreticians.<ref>[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/theatre_topics/v011/11.2saltz.html Live Media: Interactive Technology and Theatre]</ref><ref>[http://crca.ucsd.edu/views.php?id=6 Live Media Archive]</ref> Live-media relates to the gathering of relatively diverse practices capable of calling to mind the wide range of research by video producers, visual artists, musicians, sound artists, VJ's, filmmakers, designers and a range of creative people issued by creative scenes and subcultural communities. Netmage and its curators have been instrumental in coining and promoting this term.
* utilization of electronic, digital or analogue platforms to generate images and sound; * interaction consisting of visual and audio elements; * inclusion of liveness (or randomness) as in any kind of performance.
Playing with stimuli, what is created in the live-media experience is a "privilege of variation" that in the first case goes from designer to public, in the second from public to executor. The confrontation is direct, dictated by the logic of the event.
"Dispositif" (post-cinema)<ref name="popularFilm"/> and practice (Live Media) thus represent two types of continuous variation through which Netmage questions possible currents in new media aesthetics, summoning artists and visual operators from diverse disciplines, in a context reminiscent of the [[Happening]].
Despite the complexity born from the exploration of this kind of space, ideal internal space, the two axes—post-cinema and live media—intertwine and simply state what may be called a gathering, a togetherness of the community of producers, protagonists in the field of contemporary media, who both find themselves isolated; creating then a direct, interdisciplinary confrontation, thus filling a growing gap between hyper-connectivity on one hand, physical and social experience on the other.
==History== The first edition of the festival was born in an historic watershed with a view on one side from the experiences of one of the last bastions of the Twentieth Century [[avantgarde]], [[video art]], and on the other toward a new front that was as yet undefined while the entire world of research visual production was poised to turn fully digital.
In the field of music, the 1990s had already anticipated a great deal of what was later to come in the visual world, pointing the way to a radical transformation in techniques, languages and methods of cultural consumption. Netmage, different from a number of other festivals dedicated to electronics born in the world of [[nightclub|clubbing]], has concentrated on the production of images, imagination and universal vision. In eleven editions Netmage has produced and hosted over two hundred projects from over thirty countries (including Europe, Asia, The Americas, Oceania) offering a smattering of the most recent evolutions in the technological imagination and multiple currents. Follows the list of the guests of the festival (Nationality follows [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2|standard notation]])

revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |image= |name= Col. Owen J. Baggett United States Air Force |birth_date=August 29, 1920 |death_date={{death date and age|2006|7|27|1920|8|29}} |birth_place=[[Graham, Texas]] |death_place=Texas ||caption= |nickname= |allegiance={{Flag|United States of America|1912}} |branch= {{Air force|United States}} |serviceyears= |rank=Colonel |commands= |unit= [[9th Bomb Squadron]] |battles= [[World War II]] |awards= [[Prisoner of War Medal]] |laterwork= }}
'''Owen John Baggett''' (August 29, 1920 – July 27, 2006)<ref name="San Antonio EN">{{cite news|title=Owen John Baggett|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/sanantonio/obituary.aspx?n=owen-john-baggett&pid=88867663#fbLoggedOut|accessdate=21 August 2012|newspaper=San Antonio Express-News|date=30 June 2006}}</ref> was a second lieutenant in the [[United States]] 7th Bomb Group based at [[Pandaveswar]], in [[India]], during the [[Second World War]].
Baggett was born in [[Graham, Texas]] in 1920.<ref name="San Antonio EN" /> He graduated from [[Hardin–Simmons University]] in 1941, where he was the band's drum major.<ref name="San Antonio EN" /><ref name=Bethel>{{cite web|last=Bethel|first=Brian|title=Owen Baggett, 85: friend of many, good drummer, one heck of a WWII tale|url=http://www.reporternews.com/news/2006/jul/29/owen-baggett-85-friend-of-many-good-drummer-one/|work=|publisher=[[Abilene Reporter-News]]|accessdate=19 August 2012|date=29 July 2006}}</ref><ref name=Hayes>{{cite news|editor=Hayes, Harry H.|title=Owen Baggett Missing In Action|accessdate=20 August 2012|newspaper=Hardin-Simmons University Bulletin|url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth116776/m1/1/|date=April 1943|page=1}}</ref><ref name=Jones>{{cite journal|title=A War, A Legend, and Forgiveness|journal=Range Rider|date=April 2007|pages=50–51|url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth117124/|editor1-first=Jones|editor1-last=Britt Yates|publisher=Hardin-Simmons University|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150610194859/http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth117124/|archivedate=2015-06-10|df=}}</ref> He found employment on [[Wall Street]] after graduation.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keeping Up With the Exs|url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth116758/ |accessdate=21 August 2012|newspaper=Hardin-Simmons University Bulletin|date=August 1941|page=3}}</ref>
==Military service== Baggett enlisted in the [[United States Army Air Corps|Army Air Corps]] (which was subsumed by the [[Army Air Forces]] in February 1942) and graduated from pilot training on July 26, 1942, at the New Columbus Army Flying School.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keeping Up With the Exs|url=http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth116770/|accessdate=21 August 2012|newspaper=Hardin-Simmons University Bulletin|date=October 1942|page=3}}</ref>
On March 31, 1943, while stationed in British India, Baggett's [[Squadron (aviation)|squadron]], part of the [[7th Bombardment Group]], was ordered to destroy a bridge at [[Pyinmana]], [[Burma]].<ref name=Jones /> Before reaching their target, the 12 [[B-24]]s of 7th BG were intercepted by 13 [[Ki-43]] fighters of ''64 Sentai'' [[Imperial Japanese Army Air Service|IJAAS]].<ref name="young"/> Baggett's plane was severely damaged and was set on fire by several hits to the fuel tanks, and the crew was forced to bail out. The aircrew escaped the crippled B-24 merely seconds before the bomber exploded. Japanese pilots then [[Attacks on parachutists|attacked U.S. airmen as they parachuted to earth]]. Two of Baggett's fellow crew members were killed. (Contrary to sources stating that the pilot, Lloyd K. Jensen was "summarily executed", Jensen survived the war.<ref>The sources regarding Lloyd K. Jensen include Baggett's own statements in the book ''Guests of the Emperor (p. 187) and the National Archives and Records Administration, ''World War II Prisoners of War Data File, 12/7/1941 - 11/19/1946''.</ref>) Baggett, who was wounded, played dead, hoping that the Japanese pilots would ignore him. One [[Mitsubishi A6M Zero|Zero]] fighter approached close to Baggett, slowed and the pilot opened his [[aircraft canopy|canopy]]. Baggett drew his [[M1911 pistol]], fired four shots at the pilot and watched as the plane stalled and plunged toward the ground.<ref>{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Leroy|title=The Colt 1911 Pistol|year=2011|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=1849084335|page=42}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Pictorial history of the 7th Bombardment Group/Wing, 1918-1995|year=1998|publisher=7th Bombardment Group(H) Historical Foundation|isbn=096604620X|page=286}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Kelly|first=Andy|title=Magellan And I|year=2004|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=1418496456|pages=174–175}}</ref>
While Baggett later achieved fame as the only person to shoot down an aircraft with a pistol,<ref name="San Antonio EN" /><ref name=Jones /><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Frisbee |first1=John L. |last2= |first2= |year=1966 |title=Valor: David and Goliath |journal=Air Force Magazine |volume=79 |issue=7 |pages= |publisher= |doi= |url=http://www.airforce-magazine.com/MagazineArchive/Pages/1996/July%201996/0796valor.aspx |accessdate= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The M1911 Gets a Zero|url=http://www.americanrifleman.org/articles/m1911-gets-a-zero/|work=The American Rifleman|publisher=National Rifle Association|accessdate=19 August 2012|date=29 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Campbell|first=Robert K.|title=Gun Digest Shooters Guide to the 1911|year=2011|publisher=Gun Digest Books|isbn=1440218943|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dltfyqFaA68C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Gun+Digest+Shooters+Guide+to+the+1911&source=bl&ots=7KalIVDJB-&sig=lIQhWokhL6sGVY92Zu-rpmocIr4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=oDYyUNf-M-L9igLC8IDABw&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Baggett&f=false|page=24}}</ref> this was contradicted by Japanese wartime records,<ref name="young">Edward M. Young, 2012, ''B-24 Liberators vs Ki-43 Oscars'', Botley UK, Osprey, p. 57.</ref> which indicate that no Japanese pilots were lost in that particular action.<ref>{{cite book |title=Air War For Burma |author=Christopher Shores |year=2005 |page=76}}</ref>
Baggett survived the descent and was captured by Japanese ground forces. He remained a prisoner for the rest of the war.<ref name="San Antonio EN" /><ref name="Hayes" /><ref>{{cite web|last=Bourjaily|first=Phil|title=Best Shot with a 1911. Ever.|url=http://www.fieldandstream.com/blogs/gun-nuts/2011/06/best-shot-1911-ever|work=The Gun Nut|publisher=Field & Stream|accessdate=20 August 2012|date=3 June 2011}}</ref> Baggett and 37 other POWs were liberated at the war's end by eight [[Office of Strategic Services|OSS]] agents who parachuted into [[Singapore]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Dorr|first=Robert F.|title=7th Bombardment Group/Wing, 1918-1995|year=1997|publisher=Turner Publishing Company|isbn=1563112787|page=195}}</ref>
While he was assigned to [[Mitchel Air Force Base]], Baggett was noted for his work with children, including sponsoring a boy and a girl to be commander for a day.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Army, Navy, Air Force Journal|year=1953|volume=91|page=156}}</ref> Baggett retired from the Air Force as a colonel and later worked as a defense contractor manager for [[Litton Industries|Litton]].<ref name=Bethel /><ref name=Jones /><ref>{{cite book|title=Missiles and Rockets, Vol. 14|year=1964|publisher=American Aviation Publications|page=142}}</ref>
==See also== * {{Portal-inline|Biography}} * {{Portal-inline|United States Air Force}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.sightm1911.com/1911%20Myth.htm#2d%20Lt.%20Owen%20J.%20Baggett Sight M1911]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Baggett, Owen J.}} [[Category:United States Air Force officers]] [[Category:World War II prisoners of war held by Japan]] [[Category:United States Army Air Forces personnel of World War II]] [[Category:Shot-down aviators]] [[Category:People from Graham, Texas]] [[Category:American aviators]] [[Category:American prisoners of war in World War II]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]]

{{notability|Events|date=August 2014}} '''Rewired''' is the only [[Belgian]] annual [[demoparty]], which is organised since 2008. Typical competitions include [[Personal computer|PC]] demos and intros, hand-made and [[ray traced graphics]], "wild", music and "oldskool" competitions.
The first three editions took place in [[Maaseik]], [[Belgium]]. The party is organized in JC Fuego, not far from downtown Maaseik.
In 2011, the party went on a break but returned in 2012, moving the party to [[Godsheide]] near [[Hasselt]], Belgium.
== Previous editions == * ''Rewired 2008'': "Real party is outside Germany" * ''Rewired 2009'': "Summer is here" * ''Rewired 2010'': "Next Christmas arrives next Summer" * ''Rewired 2012'' * ''Rewired 2013:'' "The Garden Edition" * ''Rewired 2014'': "The Second Garden Edition"
== Upcoming editions == Currently there are no further events planned.
==External links== * [http://pouet.net/party.php?which=1439 Rewired demoparties results, reports and productions download on Pouët] * [http://www.rewired.be Rewired homepage] * [https://demozoo.org/parties/series/231/ Rewired on Demozoo]
[[Category:Demo parties]] [[Category:Competitions in Belgium]]
{{videogame-culture-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2015}} {{Tone|date=December 2007}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} [[File:Sail amsterdam 05 crowds.jpg|{{largethumb}}|SAIL Amsterdam in 2005]]
'''SAIL Amsterdam''' is a quinquennial [[sea|maritime]] event in [[Amsterdam]] in the [[Netherlands]]. [[Tall ship]]s from all over the world visit the city to moor in its eastern harbour, and people can then visit the ships.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sail.nl/en-2015|title=SAIL Amsterdam 2015 - Official website|website=www.sail.nl}}</ref>
==History== [[File:Amsterdam Sail 2010 0819 Stad Amsterdam 02.jpg|thumb|upright|The ''[[Stad Amsterdam]]'', the flagship of SAIL Amsterdam 2010]] The event was organised for the first time in 1975 to celebrate the 700th anniversary of Amsterdam, under the name 'Sail Amsterdam 700'. At that time, interest in tall ships, which had sunk to a low since the 1930s when the last commercial tall ships had been built, was starting to rise.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} The success of Sail Amsterdam 700 led to the establishment of the ''Stichting Sail Amsterdam'' (SSA, ''Foundation Sail Amsterdam'').
Sail is one of the largest maritime manifestations in the world, and the largest event of any kind in the Netherlands. Tens of tall ships and hundreds of other historical ships are involved. Numerous other ships and boats are present besides the participating ships, amounting to 8000 boats in the 2000 edition.
Lesser events take place during the festival, involving small sailboats, sailor choirs or re-enactments of naval battles. The ''Sail In'' or ''Parade of Sail'' on the first day attracts many other small ships, including creations like a sailing organ (with trumpet accompaniment) or a train converted to a ship. On the next to last day there is a naval pageant and on the last day the 'Sail Out'.
===2005 edition=== [[File:AmerigoVespucci.JPG|thumb|The [[Italian training ship Amerigo Vespucci|''Amerigo Vespucci'']] during Sail 2005]] [[File:Sailin2005.JPG|thumb|Chaos on the water during the Sail-in of 2005]] SAIL Amsterdam 2005 was held from 17 to 22 August, the 7th edition of the festival. The event was expected to attract 2 to 3 million visitors. The number of tall ships depends on the definition, but figures vary from 21 (the official figure) to over 50 (those with at least 3 masts). Other historical ships number around 600. There were also several [[ship replica]]s (either real sailing ships or fakes that have to be towed), hundreds of classical sail- and steamships ('het [[Nationaal Varend Erfgoed]]' - the Sailing National Heritage) and some modern marine ships. New that year were several modern yachts and a submarine, the ''{{ill|Hr Ms Zeeleeuw|nl|Zr.Ms. Zeeleeuw (1990)}}''.
The tall ships were moored in the [[IJhaven]] (IJ harbour) and in Amsterdam North (across [[IJ (Amsterdam)|'t IJ]]) and the Varend Erfgoed boats were moored in the {{ill|Oosterdok|nl}} nearby, where one can also find the [[Nederlands Scheepvaartmuseum]] (a [[maritime museum]]) with its (fake) replica of a [[Dutch East India Company]] (VOC) ship, which is permanently moored there. Absent was another Dutch replica of a VOC ship (a 'real' [[seaworthy]] replica), the [[Batavia (ship)|Batavia]], with its home port in [[Lelystad]], not too far from Amsterdam. [[Image:SAIL Amsterdam 2005 backlit quay.jpg|thumb|upright|Early morning overview of [[tall ships]]]]
The main ships, in the order of the official walking-route were (with length and Nation of origin): *''[[STS Sedov]]'' (117m, {{flag|Russia}}) (arrived later, on Friday) *''[[SV Tenacious|Tenacious]]'' (65 m, {{flag|Great Britain}}) *''[[Italian training ship Amerigo Vespucci|Amerigo Vespucci]]'' (104 m, {{flag|Italy}}) *''[[STS Mir|Mir]]'' (109 m, {{flag|Russia}}) *''[[Kruzenshtern (ship)|Kruzenshtern]]'' (114 m, {{flag|Russia}}) *''[[Prins Willem]]'' (the {{flag|Netherlands}}) (a replica) *''[[Stad Amsterdam]]'' (76 m, the {{flag|Netherlands}}) (the [[Flagship]]) *''[[Sørlandet (ship)|Sørlandet]]'' (64 m, {{flag|Norway}}) *''[[Europa (ship)|Europa]]'' (55 m, the {{flag|Netherlands}}) *''[[Oosterschelde (ship)|Oosterschelde]]'' (50 m, the {{flag|Netherlands}}) *''[[Eendracht (1989 ship)|Eendracht]]'' (59 m, the {{flag|Netherlands}}) *''[[NRP Sagres (1937)|Sagres]]'' (89 m, {{flag|Portugal}}) *''[[Swan fan Makkum]]'' (62m, {{flag|Netherlands}}) *''[[Alexander von Humboldt (ship)|Alexander von Humboldt]]'' (63 m, {{flag|Germany}}) *''[[Khersones (ship)|Khersones]]'' (110 m, {{flag|Ukraine}}) *''[[Pogoria (ship)|Pogoria]]'' (49 m, {{flag|Poland}}) *''[[RNOV Shabab Oman (1977)|Shabab Oman]]'' (52m, {{flag|Oman}}) *''[[Dar Młodzieży]]'' (110 m, {{flag|Poland}}) *''{{ill|Kamper Kogge|nl|Kamper kogge (schip, 1998)}}'' ({{flag|Netherlands}}) (a replica of the [[kogge]], a popular type of ship in the Netherlands in the Middle Ages) *''[[Statsraad Lehmkuhl]]'' (98 m, {{flag|Norway}}) *''[[Mircea (ship)|Mircea]]'' (81 m, {{flag|Romania}}) *''[[KRI Dewaruci|Dewaruci]]'' (63 m, {{flag|Indonesia}}) *''[[INS Tarangini (A75)|Tarangini]]'' (54 m, {{flag|India}}) *''[[Kaliakra (ship)|Kaliakra]]'' (52m, {{flag|Bulgaria}})
[[File:pieremachochel version of Prins Willem.jpg|thumb|A so-called 'Pieremachochel', the [[Prins Willem (ship replica)|''Prins Willem'']]]]
Smaller events included an exposition of yacht building in the newly built [[Muziekgebouw]] ('music building'), many music stages, food from all corners of the Earth, fireworks every night at 10 o'clock, a parade of sailors in uniform and the 'Pieremachocheltocht' (even the organisation isn't sure what the word means), a parade of carnavalesque floating creations (open to anyone).
Costs of the event were around €7.5 million. Direct financial benefits are from sponsoring, catering and sales of souvenirs.
This year's three themes were the maritime link between past, present and future, the connection of worlds and cultures and youth, with the binding motto 'Enjoy a world of friendships' (in English - the pun doesn't work in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]).
On the first day, the ships gather in the [[Lock (water transport)|locks]] at [[IJmuiden]] for the ''Sail In'' or ''Parade of Sail'' through the [[North Sea Canal]] to Amsterdam, led by the event's flagship. In 2005 that was the ''Stad Amsterdam'', which was supposed to reach Amsterdam first, but she ran aground (allegedly the fact that the Dutch crown prince [[Willem-Alexander, Prince of Orange|Willem Alexander]] was at the helm had nothing to do with that), so the Statsraad Lehmkuhl came in first (it's not a contest, though). Amsterdam's harbour is known to be very shallow (a centuries-old problem) and the Stad Amsterdam is a 'deep' ship. But luckily the ground is also very soggy, so there is not likely to have been any damage.
In 2005, {{ill|Sail Bremerhaven|de}} was held one week before SAIL Amsterdam (10–14 August) and it was decided to make that a five-yearly event as well, which will be convenient for the ships since they are already in the neighbourhood.
SAIL Amsterdam 2005 logo contest was won by Lamouri Merouane. A former student of a design school in [[Amsterdam]] (Grafisch Lyceum Amsterdam) He is originally from [[Algeria]] (Algiers). His logo was finally chosen and used through the entire event.
===2010 edition=== [[File:View02AmsterdamSail2010.JPG|thumb|upright|Welcome to Sail Amsterdam]] SAIL Amsterdam 2010 was held from 19 August until 23 August that year.
===2015 edition=== SAIL Amsterdam 2015 was held from 19 August to 23 August 2015. *[[List of sailing ships participating in Sail Amsterdam 2015]]
==See also== * [[List of large sailing vessels]] * [[List of tall ships]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Commons category-inline}} * {{nl icon}} {{official|https://www.sail.nl/ }}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=January 2010}} {{pp-move-indef}}
[[Image:Shoe tossing in Vitoria-Gasteiz (2013) 2.jpg|thumb|Shoe tossing in [[Vitoria-Gasteiz]], [[Spain]] (2013).]] '''Shoe tossing''', the act of using shoes as [[projectile]]s or improvised [[weapon]]s, is a constituent of a number of [[folklore|folk]] [[sport]]s and practices. Today, it is commonly the act of throwing a pair of [[shoes]] onto telephone wires, power lines, or other raised wires. A related practice is shoe tossing onto [[tree]]s or [[fence]]s. Urban legends tell that the shoes represent the location where a gang murder or hit took place. In urban areas, it can serve to signal that a drug dealer is nearby or one can purchase drugs in that area.
Nevertheless, the main reason for dangling shoes on high wires is for recreational or trivial purposes, usually as a prank played by bullies and drinkers. Thrown shoes may also symbolize local culture or traditions of some sort.
== Dangling shoes == {{references|section|date=February 2015}} [[File:Blick durch die Norderstraße mit den Hängenden Schuhen zur Marienkirche (Flensburg), Bild 01.JPG|thumb|Because of the Shoefiti the ''Norderstraße'' (Northern Street) in [[Flensburg]], Germany, is named by the New Yorker travel magazine [[Travel + Leisure]] to one of the "World's Strangest Streets".]] Shoe dangling, or shoe flinging, is the practice of throwing shoes whose [[shoelace]]s have been tied together so that they hang from overhead [[wire]]s such as [[electric power transmission|power line]]s or [[telephone]] cables. Once the shoes are tied together, the pair is then thrown at the wires as a sort of [[bolas]].
Shoe flinging occurs throughout North America, Latin America and Europe, in rural as well as in urban areas. Usually, the shoes flung at the wires are [[Sneaker (footwear)|sneakers]]; many different varieties of shoes, including [[leather]] shoes and [[boot]]s, also are thrown.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.wbez.org/shows/curious-city/shoes-on-a-wire-untangling-an-urban-myth/f46d882f-dd38-452b-98dc-be406135429a|title=Shoes on a Wire: Untangling an Urban Myth|work=WBEZ|access-date=2017-04-26|language=en}}</ref> There are many cultural variations as well, with differences between socio-economic areas and even age groups. [[Image:Philmont Scout Ranch boots around sign.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Boy Scout]] throws his boots over the [[Philmont]] entrance sign at Base Camp, a longstanding tradition]]
=== Purpose === A number of criminal explanations have been proposed as to why this is done. The foremost is bullying in which a bully steals a pair of shoes and puts them in a place where they are unlikely to be retrieved.<ref name=":0" /> Or sometimes it is done as a [[practical joke]] played on [[drunkenness|drunkards]].<ref name="sd" /> An April/May 2003 newsletter from the now former mayor of [[Los Angeles, California]], Mayor James Hahn, cited fears of many Los Angeles residents that "these shoes indicate sites at which drugs are sold or worse yet, gang turf", and that city and utility employees had launched a program to remove the shoes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lacity.org/mayor/teamworkla/newsletters/teamworkla_intrnewsletters72311897_06102003.pdf |title= East Los Angeles NSC Combats Problem of Overhead Shoes on Wires |accessdate= 2007-06-15 |author= TeamWork LA |year= c. 2003 |format= PDF |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20031007130106/http://www.lacity.org/mayor/teamworkla/newsletters/teamworkla_intrnewsletters72311897_06102003.pdf |archivedate=2003-10-07}}</ref> A 2015 study of shoe tossing data in Chicago found that the rumor and relationship between dangling shoes and drug dealing was [[Correlation does not imply causation|correlated, not causal]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wbez.org/shows/curious-city/shoes-on-a-wire-untangling-an-urban-myth/f46d882f-dd38-452b-98dc-be406135429a|title=Shoes on a Wire: Untangling an Urban Myth|work=WBEZ|access-date=2018-10-24|language=en}}</ref>
Other, less criminal explanations have been proposed. In some cultures, shoes are flung to commemorate the end of a [[school]] year, or a forthcoming [[marriage]], as part of a [[rite of passage]]. It has been suggested that the custom may have originated with members of the [[military]], who are said to have thrown military boots, often painted orange or some other conspicuous color, at overhead wires as a part of a rite of passage upon completing [[basic training]] or on leaving the service.<ref name=sd>Adams Cecil (August 2, 1996). [http://www.straightdope.com/classics/a5_274.html Why do you see pairs of shoes hanging by the laces from power lines?] ''[[The Straight Dope]]''.</ref> In the 1997 [[film]] ''[[Wag the Dog]]'', shoe tossing features as an allegedly spontaneous cultural manifestation of tribute to Sgt. William Schumann, played by [[Woody Harrelson]], who has purportedly been “shot down behind enemy lines” in [[Albania]].
In the [[List of Better Call Saul episodes|''Better Call Saul'' episode]] "Sunk Costs", a pair of dangling shoes is used to surreptitiously plant illegal drugs on a truck.
Others simply say that shoe flinging is a way to get rid of shoes that are no longer wanted, are uncomfortable, or do not fit.<ref name=hub>Wordscribe41. "Shoefiti: Unique Urban Street Art". Hubpages.</ref>{{Verify source|date=February 2012}} It may also be another manifestation of the human instinct to [[territorial marking|leave their mark on]], and decorate, their surroundings.<ref name=sd/>
In some neighborhoods, shoes tied together and hanging from power lines or tree branches signify that someone has died. The shoes belong to the dead person. The reason they are hanging, legend has it, is that when the dead person's spirit returns, it will walk that high above the ground, that much closer to heaven.<ref name=hub/>{{Verify source|date=February 2012}} Another superstition holds that the tossing of shoes over the power lines outside of a house is a way to keep the property safe from ghosts. Yet another legend suggests that shoes hanging from telephone wires signal someone leaving the neighborhood onto bigger and better things.<ref>Whitley, Peggy, Becky Bradley, Bettye Sutton, and Sue Goodwin. "1990-1999." American Cultural History. Lone Star College-Kingwood Library. Last modified February 2011. http://wwwappskc.lonestar.edu/ popculture/decade90.html.</ref><ref>Alarcão, Jorge de (1988). Roman Portugal. Volume I: Introduction (p. 93). Warminster: Aris and Phillips</ref>
==Shoe tree== [[Image:Quail 11 bg 041506.jpg|thumb|The Shoe Tree in Morley Field, San Diego.<ref>The Shoe Tree in Frisbee Playground, Morley Field, San Diego fell down (allegedly on January 7, 2008, confirmed the following day), caused by a long period of rain.</ref>]]
A [[Shoe Tree|shoe tree]], not to be confused with the shoe-preservation device [[Shoe tree|of the same name]], is a [[tree]] (or, occasionally, a powerline pole or other wooden object) that has been festooned with old shoes.<ref>[http://www.roadsideamerica.com/set/shoetrees.html Shoe Trees]. Roadside America.</ref> Shoe trees are generally located alongside a major local thoroughfare, and may have a theme (such as [[high-heeled shoe]]s). There are currently at least seventy-six such shoe trees in the United States,<ref>Roadside America. [http://www.roadsideamerica.com/roger/QueryTips.php3?tip_AttractionName=shoe+tree&tip_Town=&tip_State=&Submit=Find Search results for "shoe tree."]</ref> and an undetermined number elsewhere.
== Competitive boot throwing == {{unreferenced section|date=October 2012}} [[File:Boot throwing.ogg|thumb|left|Boot throwing in Finland.]] {{also|Wellie wanging}} '''Boot throwing''', or welly wanging, has been a competitive sport in [[New Zealand]] and Britain for many years, although not one that is taken very seriously. [[Wellington boot]]s are the heavy rubber boots worn by most farm workers and many other outdoor workers. A competition to see who can throw a boot, or "welly", the furthest is a feature of many Agricultural Field Days in the rural communities. The town of [[Taihape]] in the central [[North Island]] is particularly identified with this sport; they claim to be the Gum Boot Throwing Capital of New Zealand. They hold an annual competition ([[Gumboot Day]]) in the main street and award a Golden Gumboot as the trophy. See also [[Wellie wanging]] in [[Yorkshire]], England.
Since 2003 the sport has been practiced competitively in [[Eastern Europe]]. The 2004 World Championship Competition was won by Germany who is hosting the 2005 Competition at [[Döbeln]]. Teams were also expected from [[Australia]] and [[Russia]]. Boot throwing has been a popular sport in [[Finland]] since 1976 when the first Finnish Championships of boot throwing was organized. {{-}}
The Scottish Championships were held in Oban in July 2009 where shoe-throwing pioneers RD Miller & David Gaffney created an impromptu event on the waterfront. This inspired such shoe-throwing legends as Phil Reid (who always favoured the lighter trainer) to pick up the baton -- or the sneaker in this case -- and take it to a wider audience. A more amateur watered-down version is still evident today in certain parts of Oban in July.
== Insult == {{see also|List of shoe throwing incidents}} In many [[Arab people|Arab]] cultures, it is considered an extreme insult to throw a shoe at someone. It is also considered rude even to display the [[Sole (foot)|sole]] of one's foot to someone. In 2008, Iraqi cameraman [[Muntadar al-Zaidi]] threw two shoes at [[United States]] President [[George W. Bush]] while the president was visiting [[Baghdad]], and was arrested and incarcerated. President Bush ducked and was not struck by the shoes.<ref name="Asser_Martin">{{cite web |last=Asser|first=Martin |title=Bush shoe-ing worst Arab insult |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7783325.stm |accessdate=July 22, 2012 |publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=December 15, 2008}}</ref> Shoe throwing as an insult is not just limited to the Muslim world, as there are also other notable incidents that have occurred involving other [[celebrity|celebrities]] and world leaders. Some of these have involved [[Steve McCarthy (boxer)|Steve McCarthy]], [[David Beckham]], [[Harry Styles]], [[Lily Allen]], [[Hillary Clinton]], and [[Wen Jiabao]].<ref name="metro_shoe">{{cite news|title=Top 5 famous shoe throwing incidents |url=http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/615122-top-5-famous-shoe-throwing-incidents |newspaper=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]}}</ref>
== Flipper tossing == [[File:Flippers on a wire2.jpg|thumb|Pair of flippers (water footwear) hanging from a wire at 4th Ave. and E 10th St, New York, NY]] "Flippering" has occurred in the Stoke Croft area of Bristol; a pair of flippers can be seen on Jamaica Street in Bristol.{{cite needed|date=May 2017}} Flippers have also been seen over a wire in the East Village section of New York City (pictured).
==See also== * [[Abandoned footwear]] * [[Gumboot Day]] * [[Panty tree]] * [[Wellie wanging]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== {{sisterlinks|shoe tossing}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090608184116/http://bootthrowing.com/online/etusivu/?lan=EN Bootthrowers' House] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/8334137.stm Close-Up: New York's hanging sneakers] – [[BBC News]] report looking at the phenomenon
<!-- [[ja:靴を投げる]] No such article -->
[[Category:American folklore]] [[Category:Children's games]] [[Category:Urban legends]] [[Category:Uses of shoes]] [[Category:Vandalism]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]
